Oxford transcription team, 1992-1998: Peter Robinson, Elizabeth Solopova, Lorna Stevenson, with contributions from James McCabe, Hubert Stadler, Cathy Swires, Paul and Maureen Watry, Laura Wright, Diana Wyatt and Simon Horobin
Sheffield transcription team, 1992-1998, led by Norman Blake: Michael Pidd and Estelle Stubbs, with Linda Cross, Claire Thomson and Simon Horobin

Brigham Young University transcription team, 1995-2006, led by Paul Thomas: Sara Black, Jessica Cox, Barbara Christiansen, Kerry Clift Spencer*, Heidi Elldredge, Leona Fisher Sankhla, Kela Flint*, Melissa Gallup, Shannon Harris, Rebecca Johnson, Mary Jorgensen, Darin Merrill*, Wesley Pack*, Jared Perkins, Jon Penny, Randall Rogers, Ryan Rowberry*, Sara Slack, Carie Soderquist Jackson*, Kat Southerland, Matt Tenney, Briton Wright, John Young. University of Sheffield, 1994-1999, led by Norman Blake: Michael Pidd and Estelle Stubbs, with Linda Cross, Claire Thomson, Orietta Da Rold and Simon Horobin. In partnership with the Canterbury Tales Project, at that time led by Norman Blake in partnership with Peter Robinson and Elizabeth Solopova (up to 1998), and using images and other resources supplied by the Project, the Sheffield team transcribed eight manuscripts in full (Ad3, Corpus, Dd, Gg, Ellesmere, Ha4, Hengwrt, Lansdowne), sections of some seven other manuscripts, and all manuscripts of the Franklin's Tale. No part of these transcripts is contained in this iteration of the Project.

div.l: WHan that Aprill wit his shoures soote
The drought of marche hath ꝑperced to þe roote
And bathed euery Veyne in swich licoure
Of which v̉ertue engendrid is þe floure
Whan zephirus ek wit his swete brethe
Inspirid hath in eủery holt and hethe
The tendre croppes ⁊and the ȝonge sonne
Hath in the ram his half cours y . ronne
And smale foules make melodye .
That slepen alnyght open eyghe
So priketh hem nature in here corages
Than longen folk to gon on pilgmages
And Palmeres for to seke straungre strondes
To ferne halowes cowthe in sondri londes
And speciali fᵃm eủery schires ende
Of Englond to Canturburi þei wende
The holi blisseful martir for to seke
That hem hath holpen whan þat þei wer seke
Bifill þat in þat sesou on a Day
In Southwerk atte Tabbard as I. lay
Redi to wende on my pilgⁱmage
To Cant̉erbury with ful deuoute corage
At nyght was come in to that hostillerie
Wel . xxix . on a companie
Of sondry folk by auenture yfalle
In felaschipe ⁊and pilgⁱmes were thei alle
That toward Canturbury wolde ride
The chambres and stables were wyde
And wel weren esed atte beste
And shortly whan the sonne was to reste
So hadde I spoken wit hem eủerychon
That I was of her felaschipe a non .
And mad forward erly for to rise
To take our wey þere as I yow deuyse
But natheles whil I haue tyme ⁊and space
Or that I ferther in this tale pace
Me thynketh it acordant to resoıı̄un
To telle yow al þe condicioıı̄un
Of ech of hem so as it semed me
And whoche þei were and of what degr
And eke in what array that they were Inne
And at a knyght þan wolde I. ferst bi gynne
A knight þer was ⁊and that a worthi man
That fro the tyme that he ferst bigan
To riden out he louede chiualrie
Treuthe and honoᵘur fredom ⁊and curtesye
Ful worthi was he in his lordes werre
And therto had he riden noman ferre
As wel in cⁱstendom as in hethenesse
And eủere honoured for his worthinesse
¶ At Alisandre he was whan it was wōnne
Ful ofte tyme he had the bord bi gōnne
A bouen alle nacoıı̄uns in Pruce
In lectow had he reysyd and in Ruce
¶ No cⁱsten man so ofte of his degree
In Gernade at the sege ek hadde he be
Of algezire and riden in Belmarye
At lyeis was he and at Satalye
When þei were wōnne ⁊and in the grete see
At many a noble arme had he be
At mortel batailles had he ben fyftene
And foughten for our faith at tramessene
In lystes thries and ay slayn his foo
This ilke worthy knyght hadde ben also
Som tyme with the lord of Palatye
Ayein an other hethen in Turkye
And eủere more he hadde a souerayne prys
And though þat he was worthi he was wys
And of his port as meke as is a mayde
He neủere ȝet no velonye ne sayde
In all his lif vn to no mane . wyght
He was a verrey ꝑperfyt gentill knyght
For to tellen ȝow of his array
His hors were gode . but he was not gay
Of fustioıı̄un he werede a gepoıı̄un
Al by smotered wit his haburgeou
For he was late y come from his viage
And went for to don his pilgⁱmage
¶ Wit hym þer was his sone a ȝong Squier
A louyere and a lusty bacheller
Wit lokkes crulle as þei were leyd in press
Of .xx. ȝeer of age he was I gesse
Of his stature he was of euene lengthe
And wonderly delyuere ⁊and gret of strengthe
And he hadde be somtyme in chiuachye
In flaundres in Artoys and pykardie
And born hym wel as of so litel space
In hope to stonden in his lady grace
Embroyded was he as it were a mede
All ful of fresche floures white ⁊and rede
Syngynge he was or floytynge al þe day
He was as fresch. as is þe moneþ of may
Short was his gowne wiþ sleues longe ⁊and wyde
Wel cowde he sitte on an hors ⁊and fair ride
He cowde songes make ⁊and wel endyte
Iuste and ek daunce ⁊and wel purteray ⁊and wryte
So hote he loued þat bi nyght̉er tale
He slepte namore than doth a nyghtyngale
Corteys he was lowely and seruisable
And karf bi forn his fader atte table
¶ A noþ̉er yeman hadde he ⁊and ʆseruantes no mo
At þat tyme for hym liste ride so
And he was clad in coote ⁊and hood of grene
A scheef of pocok arwes bryght ⁊and kene
Vndir his belt he bar ful thriftylly
Wel couthe he dresse his takel . ȝimanly
His arwes drouped noght wit fetheres lowe
And in his hond he bar a myghty bowe
A not hed hadde he wit a broun visage
Of wode crafte wel couþe he al þe vsage
Vp on his arme he bar a gay bracer
⁊and bi his side a swerd ⁊and a Bokeler
And on þat oþ̉er syde a gay Daggere
Harnaysed wel ⁊and scharp as poynt of spere
A xpophre on his breste of seluer shene
An horn he bar the baudryk was of grene
A forster was he sothly as y gesse
¶ Ther was also a Nonne a Prioresse
That of hir smyling was ful symple ⁊and coy
Hire grettest ooth was but be seint loy
And she was cleped ma dame Engletyn
Fol wel she songe þe suise dyuine
Entuned in hir nose ful semely
And frenssh she spak ful fayr ⁊and fetisly
After the scole of Stratford atte Bowe
For frenssh of Parys was to hir vn knowe
At meete wel y taught was she wit alle
She leet no morsell from hire lippes falle
Ne wete hire fyngres in hire sauce depe
Wel cowthe she carye a morsel ⁊and wel kepe
That no drope ne fill vp on hire breste
In curteysye was sette ful mochel hir leste
Hire ouerlippe wyped sche so clene
That in hir cuppe þ̉er was no ferthing sene
Of grece whan she dronken hadde hire draughte
Ful semely aft̉er hire mete she raughte
And sikerly she was of gret disporte
And ful plesante ⁊and amyable of porte
And peyned hir to counterfete chere
Of court ⁊and to ben estatlich of manere
But for to speken of hir concience
She was so charitable and so pytous
She wolde wepe ȝyf þat she saw a mous
Kaught in a trappe yf it wer ded or bledde
Of smale houndes had she þat she fedde
Wit rosted flessh or mylk or wastelbrede
But sore wepte she ȝyf on of hem were dede
Or yf men smot yt wit a ȝerde smerte
And al was conscience ⁊and tendr herte
Ful semelich hir wympil pynchid was
Hire nose was streght hir eighen grey as glas
Hire mouth ful smal ⁊and þ̉erto softe and rede
But sekyrly she hadde a faire forhede
It was almost a spanne brood I. trowe
For hardely she was nought vndergrowe
Ful fetys was hir cloke as I. was war
Of smal coral a bowte hir arm she bar
A payre of bedes gauded al wit grene
And þer on heng a broche of gold ful shene
On which þer was first writen a crowned .A.
And aft̉er Amor vincit omīnia
An other Nonne wit hire hadde she
That was hir chapelleyne ⁊and preestes thre
¶ A Monk þ̉er was a fair for the Maystrye
An owt Ridere that loved venerye
A manly man to ben an abbot able
Ful Many a deynte hors hadde he in stable
And whan he rood men myghte his bridel here
Gynglyng in a whistelyng wynd as clere
And eke as lowde as doth the chapel belle
Ther as this lord was keper of the selle
The rewle of seynt Maur or of seint Benet
Bi cause that it was old and somdel streit
This ilke Monk leet olde thinges pace
And held after þe newe world þe space
He yaf nought of the text a pulled hen
That seith that hunters be nought holi men .
Ne that a Monk whan he is recheles
Is likned till a Fyssh . þat is wat̉erles
This is to seie Amonk owt of his Cloystre
But thilke text held he nought worth an oystre
And I seyde his Opynioıı̄un was goode
What shulde he studye ⁊and make hīm self woode
Vppon a booke in Cloystre al wey to poure
Or swynk wit his hondis and laboure
As Austyn bit how schal þe world bi serued
Lat Austyn haue his swynk to hym reserued
Ther fore he was a pⁱripasour a right
Grehoundes he hadde as swift as foule in flyght
Of Prikynge ⁊and of huntyng for the hare
Was al his luste for no coste wolde he spare
I seigh his slefes I pʳfiled at the hond
Wit grys ⁊and that the fyneste of a lond
And for to festne his hood vndir þᵉ chynne
He hadde of gold wrought a ful curious pynne
A loue knotte in the gretter ende þer was
His hed was balled that shon as ony glas
And eke his face as he hadde ben anoynt
He was a lord ful fat ⁊and in good poynt
His eyghen stepe and rollyng in his hede
That stemed as a forneys of a led
His botes souple his hors in gret estate
Now c̉erteynly he was a fair prelate
He nas nat pale as a forpyned goost
A fat swan louede he best of any roost
His palfray was as broun as is a berye
A frere þer was a wantoıı̄un ⁊and merye
A lymitour a ful solempne man
In alle þe ordres foure is noon þat can
So mochel of daliaunce ⁊and fayr langage
He hadde made ful many a Mariage
Of ȝonge wōmmēn at his owne cost
Vn to his ordre he was a noble post
Ful wel bi lovid ⁊and famulier was he
Wit Frankeleyns ouer al in his contre
And wit worthi wōmmen of þe toun
For he hadde power of confessioun
As sayde hym self more þān a curat
For his ordre he was licenciat
Ful sweteli herde he confession
And plesant was his absolucom
He was an esy man to ȝefe penance
Ther as he wiste to haue a gode pitance
For vn to a poure . ordre for to ȝyue
Is signe that a man is wele I shryue
For yf he yaf he dorste make auant
He wiste that a man was repentant
For many a man is so hard of his herte
He may nought wepe al þogh him sore smerte
Ther fore in stede of wepyng and preyeres
Men mote yeve siluer to the poủere freres
His typet was ay farsed ful of knyfes
And pynnes for to yeue fair wifes
And c̉ertaynly he had a mery note
Wel cowthe he syngen ⁊and playen on a rote
Of ȝeddinges he bar wittly the pris
His nekke whigt was as the flour delys
Ther to he was stronge as a champyoıı̄un
He knew the taủernes wel in eủery toıı̄un
And eủerich hostiller and tapster
Betᵗʳ than a lazer or a Begge
For vn to swich a worthi man as he
Acorded noght as by hys faculte
To haue with swich seke lazer aquayntance
It is nouȝt honest it may not avaunce
For to delen wit swich . poraylle
But all wᵗith Riche ⁊and seller of vitaille
And oủer al þer as ꝓprofyt scholde a rise
Curtays he was and lowely of suyse
Ther nas no man noghwer so v̉ertuous
He was the beste begger in his hous
For thogh a widewe hadde noght a sho
So plesant was his In Principio
Yet wolde he haue a Ferthing or he wente
His purchace was wel better þan his rente
And rage he couthe right as it were a whelpe
In louedayes þer cowthe he moche helpe
For ther he was not lyke a cloistrer
Wit a thred bare cope as a pore scoler
But he was lyke a Maister or a pope
Of double worstede was his semy cope
That rounded as a belle on the presse
Somwhat he lipsede for his wantounesse
To make his Englisch swete vppon his tonge
And in his harpyng whan that he hadde songe
Hys eyghen twynklede in his hede a Right
As don þe sterres in the frosty nyght
This worthi lymitoᵘur was clepid huberd
A marchant was thare wit a forked berd
In mottle ⁊and heygh on horse he satte
Vp on his heued a Flaundrisshe beuer hatte
His botis clapsid fair ⁊and fetyslye
His resons he spak ful solempnelye
Shewyng al wey the encres of his wynyge
He wolde the see were kept for any thynge
By twixe Middilburgh and Orewell
Wel couthe he in eschaunge sheldes selle
This worthi man ful wel his witte bi sette
Ther wiste no whight þat he was in dette
So estatly was he of his goủernance
Wit his Bargaynes and wᵗith his cheuissaıı̄unc
For sothe he was a worthi man wit alle
But sothelich to seyn I not how mēn hīm calle
A n clerc þ̉er was of Oxenforde also
That vnto logyk hadde longe y go
As lene was his hors as is a rake
And he nas not ryght fat I vndirtake
But loked holowe and þerto soburly
Ful thredbare was his oủereste Courtepy
For he hadde getyn him no benefice
Ne was so worldly to haue office
For hym was leuer haue at his bedde hede
Twenty bokes clad in blak ⁊and rede
Of Aristotle ⁊and his philosophie
Than robes Riche or fythel or gay sawt̉erye
But al bi that he was a philosophre
Yet hadde he but litill gold in coffre
But al that he myghte of his frendes hente
On bokes and on lernyng he it spente
And besyly gan for þo soules preie
Of hem that yaf hym whar wit forto scoleye
Of studie took he most cure ⁊and hede
Naught a word spake he more þan was nede
And þat was seid informe ⁊and reủerence
And short ⁊and quyk ⁊and ful of heigh sentence
Sownyng in morall vertue was his speche
And gladly wolde he lerne ⁊and gladly teche
A sergeant of the lawe war and wys
That often had ben at Paruys
That was also ful riche of excellence
Discret he was ⁊and of gret reủerence
He semyd swich his wordes weren so wyse
Iustice he was ful often in Assise
Bi patent and bi pleyne cōmmissioıı̄un
For his science ⁊and for his hyegh . renoıı̄un
Of fees ⁊and Robes hadde he many on
So gret a purchaceoᵘur was nowher non
Al was fee symple to him in effecte
His pʳchasyng myght nought ben in fecte
Nowher so besy a man as he þer nas
And ȝet he semed besier þan he wa
In t̉ermes hadde he caas ⁊and domes alle
That from the tyme of kyng willᵃm wer falle
Therto he cowthe endite ⁊and make a think
Ther cowthe no whight pynche at his writink
And eủery statut cowthe he pleyn bi Rote
He rood but homly in a medle coote
Gert wᵗith a seynt of selk wit barres smale
Of his array telle I no leng tale
A frankeleyn was in his companie
White was his berd as is the dayessye
Of his complexcioıı̄un he was sangwyne
Wel loued he by the morowe a sop in wyne
To lyuen in delyt eủere was his wone
For he was Epicurues oune sone
That held opyniou that pleyn delite
Was verrey felicite ꝑperfite
An housholder and that a gret was he
Seynt Iuliānn he was in his contre
His breed his ale was alleweys after one
A better envyned man was nowher none
Wit oute bakemete was neủere his hous
Of fissh ⁊and flessh and þat so plentyuous
It snewid in his hous of mete ⁊and drink
Of alle deyntethes þat men cowthe think
Aft̉er þe sondri sesons of the yere
So changet he his mete ⁊and his sopere
Ful many a fat partⁱch hadde he īm Mewe
And many a brem ⁊and many a luce in stuwe
Wo was his coke but his sauce were
Poynant ⁊and scharp and redy al his gere
His table dormant in his halle al way
Stod redy coủered alle þe longe day
At sessions ther was he lord ⁊and sire
Ful ofte tyme he was knyght of the shire
An anelas ⁊and a gipser al of silke
Heng at his girdel whight as morne mylke
A scherref had he ben ⁊and a compatour
Was nowher swich a worthi vauasour
An haburdassher and a carpenter
A Webbe A . Dyere ⁊and a Tapece
And thei were clothed alle in oo liủere
Of a solempne ⁊and a gret frat̉ernite
Ful fressh ⁊and newe here gere a piged was
Here knyfes ner chaped nouȝt wit bras
But alle wᵗith siluer wroght ful clene ⁊and wel
Her gerdeles ⁊and her pouches euerydel
Wel semed eche of hem a fair burgeys
To sitten in a yeldhalle on a deys
Eủerich for the wisdom that he can
Was shaply for to ben an Alderman
For catell hadde thei I. nough ⁊and Rente
And eke her wyues wolde it wel assente
And ellis c̉ertein thei were to blame
It is ful fair to be clepid madame
And gon to vigilies al bi fore
And haue a mantel rialliche I bore
A cook thei hadde wit hem for the nones
To boille þe chikenes wᵗith þe Mariebones
And poudr marchant tart ⁊and galyngale
Wel cowthe he knowe a draught of londen ale
He couthe roost ⁊and sethe ⁊and broille and frye
Maken mortreux and wel bake a pye
But gret harm was it as it thoghte me
That on his schyne a mormal hadde he
For blank manger þat made he wit þe beste
A schip man was there wonyng fer bi weste
For ought I woot he was of Dertemouthe
He rood vp on a Rouncy as he couthe
In a gowne of faldyng to the kne
A dagger hangynge in a lace hadde he
A bowten his nekke vndir his harm down
The hote somer hadde mad his hiew al brown
And c̉erteinly he was a good felawe
Ful many a draught of wyn hadde he drawe
From Burdeux ward while þe chapmen slepe
Of nyce conscience toke he no kepe
Yf þat he faught ⁊and hadde þe heigher honde
Bi watir he sent hem hom to euery londe
But of his craft to riken wel his tydes
His stremys and his daunger him biside
His herberwe ⁊and his moone ⁊and his ledmannage
Ther nas noon swich fro hull to kartage
Hardy he was ⁊and wys to vndirtake
Wit many atempest hadde his berd bi shake
He knew alle the hauenes as thei were
Fro Gotlond to the Cape defynystere
And eủery Cryke in Bretaigne ⁊and in Spayne
His barge y clepid was the Mawdeleyne
Wit vs þer was a doctour of phisik
In al this werld ne was þ̉er noon him lyke
To speke of phisik ⁊and of Surgerie
For he was grownded in Astronomye
He kept his pacient a ful gret del
In houres bi his magik naturel
Wel cowthe he fortune the ascendent
Of his ymages for his paciet
He knewe the cause of eủerich maladye
Were it of hoot or colde or moiste or drie
And wher engendred ⁊and of what humoᵘur
He was a verrey ꝑparfit practisour
The cause I knowe ⁊and of his harm þe rote
A non he yaf the sike man his bote
Ful redy hadde he his appotekaries
To sende hem drugges and his letuaries
For ech of hem made other for to wynne
Her frendschipe nas not newe for to gynne
Wel knew he the olde Escalapius
And discorides ⁊and eke Rufus
Olde ypocᵃs haly and galien
Serapion Razie and auyzen
Aueroys damascien ⁊and constantine
Bernard ⁊and Gatisdene ⁊and Gilbertine
Of his diete mesurable was he
For it was of no suꝑperfluite
But of gret norsshing ⁊and digestable
His studie was but litil on þe bible
In sangwyne and in pers he clad was al
Lyned wit Taffata ⁊and wit sendal
And yet ⁊and was but esy of dispense
He kept þat he wan in pestilense
For gold in Phisik is accordia
Ther fore he loued gold in special
A gode wif þ̉er was of bi side þe bathe
But sche was somdel Def ⁊and þat was scathe
Of cloth makyng she had swich an haunte
She passide hem of ypres and of Gaunte
In alle þe parisshe wif ne was þ̉er noon
Þat to þe offryng to forn hir schulde goon
And yf þ̉er dede c̉erteyn wroth was she
That she was owte of alle charite
Hire coủerchiefs ful fyne were of gᵒunde
Y dorste swere thei weyeden ten pounde
That on a soneday weren vp on hir hede
Hire hosyn weren of fyn scarlet rede
Ful streyt y teyed and shoos ful moyste ⁊and newe
Bolde was hir face and fair ⁊and rede of hiewe
She was a worthi wōmman al hir lyue
Housbondes atte chirche dore she hadde fyue
Wit outen other companye in youthe
But ther of nedyþ noght to speke as nouthe
And þries hadde she ben at Ierlm
She hadde passid many a strange strem
At Rome sche hadde ben ⁊and at boloigne
In Galice at seynt Iame ⁊and at Coloigne
She couthe moche on wandringe bi the weie

I wympled wel and on hire hede an hatte
As brood as is a bokeler or a targe
A fote mantell a bowtēm hir hipes large

In felaschipe wel couthe sche laughe ⁊and carpe

A goode man was thare of religioıı̄un
And was a powr ꝑparson of a town
But riche he was of holy þoght ⁊and werk
He was also a lerned man ⁊and a clerk
That cⁱristys gospell treweli wolde preche
His parisshyns deuoutely wolde he teche
Benigne he was ⁊and wondir diligent
And in adủersite ful pacien
And swich he was preuyd ofte sythes
Ful loth were him to cursyn for his tythes
But rather wolde he yeuen out of doute
Vnto his poure parisshens a boute
Of his offring ⁊and of his substance
He couthe in litil thyng haue suffisance
Wyde was his parisshe ⁊and houses fer a sondre
But he ne laft nought for rayne ne thundre
In syknesse nor in meschief to visite
The ferreste in his parisshe muche ⁊and lite
Vpon his feet and in his honde a staf
This noble ensample to his shepe he yaf
That ferst he wroughte ⁊and after ward þᵗat he tauȝt
Owt of þe gospell he þo wordes kaught
And this figure he addede ek þer to
That yf gold ruste what schal Iren do
For yf a preest be foul on whom we truste
No wondir is a lewid man to ruste
And shame it is yf a prest take kepe
A shiten shepꝑparde ⁊and a clene shepe
Weel ought a preest ensample for to ȝyue
Bi his clennes how þᵗat his shepe schulde lyue
He set naught his benefice to hir
And leet his sheep a combred in þe myre
And ran to londou vnto seynt Poules
To seke hym a Chaunterye for soules
Or wit a bretherhed to ben wit holde
But dwelte at hom ⁊and kepte wel his folde
So that þe wolf ne made it not myscarie
He was a sheꝑparde ⁊and not a mercenarie
And thought he holi ⁊and v̉ertuous were
He was nought to synful men dispitous
Ne of his speche daungous ne digne
But in his teching discret and benīngne
To drawen folk to heuen bi fairnesse
Bi good emsample þis was his bisynesse
But it were ony ꝑparsoıı̄un obstinate
What so he were of heygh or low estate
Hym wolde he snebbe sharply for þᵉ nones
A bett̉er preest Y trowe þat now here non es
He waytede after no pompe ⁊and reủerenc
Ne maked hym a spiced conscience
But Cⁱstes lore and his aposteles twelue
He taught but ferst he folwed in him selue
Wit hym þ̉er was a ploweman was his brother
That hadde I ladde of dong ful many a fother
And a trewe swynker ⁊and a good was he
Leuynge in pees and ꝑperfite charite
God loued he best wᵗith alle his herte
At alle tymes þough he gamede or smte
And þan his neyghebore riȝt as him selue
He wolde thesshe ⁊and þ̉erto dyke and delue
For cⁱstes sake for euery poủere wight
Wit oute hir yf it lay in his myght
His tithes paied he ful fair and well
Bothen of his ꝓpropre swynk ⁊and his catell
In a tabbard he rood vp on a mere
Ther was also a Reue and a Mellere
A sompnoᵘur and a Pardon also
A Maunciple and my self þer nare nomo .
The mellere was a stout carle for þe nones
Ful big he was of brawn ⁊and ek of bones
That ꝓproued wel for oủer all þere he cam
Atte wrastelyng he wolde haue a wey þe ram
He was schort schuldred a thikke knarre
Ther was no dore þat he wolde heue of harre
Or breke it at a rennynge with his hede
His berd as any sow or fox was reede
And þerto brood as þough it were a spade
Vppon þe cop ryght of his nose he hade
A wert And þ̉eron stod a tuft of heris

His nose þrilles blak were ⁊and wide
A swerd and a bokeler bar he be his syde

He was a Iangler ⁊and a galiardeis
And þat was most of synne ⁊and of harlotries

For to ben wyse in buyng / of vytaille
For whethur þat he paied or toke bi taille
Al gate he waited so in his achate

Now is not þat of god a ful faire grace

His wonyng was ful fair vppon an heth

He couthe bettre þan his lord pᵃchace
Ful Riche he was a stored pⁱriuyl
His lord he cowthe wel plesen subtili

And haue a thank and yet a coote ⁊and an hode
In youthe he hadde lerned a good mistere
He was a wel good wryghte a carpentere

A long surcote of peers vppon he hadde

A Somynour was þer wit vs in þat place

A fewe t̉ermes hadde he two or thre

No wonder is . he herde it al the day
And yk ye knowen it wel how þat a Iay
Kane clepe watte as wel as can the pope

Ay questio quid Iurꝭes wolde he crye
He was a gentil harlot and a kynde
A better felaw shul men not fynde

Ful pⁱriuyli ek a fynch couþe he pulle

¶ Now haue I tolde yow sotheli in a clause

But ferst y pray yow of yowre curtesie

div.l: (base) This duc of whom I make mencioun
(base) Whanne he was come / almoost to the town
(base) In al his wele / and in his mooste pryde
(base) He was war / as he caste his eye asyde
(base) Wher that ther kneled / in the heighe weye
(base) A compaignye of ladyes / tweye and tweye
(base) Ech after /oother clad in clothes blake
(base) But swich a cry / and swich a wo they make
(base) That in this world / nys creature lyuynge
(base) That herde / swich another waymentynge
(base) And of this cry / they nolde neuere stenten
(base) Til they / the reynes of his brydel henten
(base) ¶ What folk been ye / that at myn hom comynge
(base) Perturben so my feste / with cryynge
(base) Quod Theseus / haue ye so greet envie
(base) Of myn honour / that thus compleyne and crye
(base) Or who hath yow mysboden / or offended
(base) And telleth me / if it may been amended
(base) And why that ye / been clothed thus in blak /
(base) The eldeste lady / of hem alle spak
(base) Whan she hadde swowned / with a deedly cheere
(base) That it was routhe / for to seen and heere
(base) ¶ She seyde / lord / to whom Fortune hath yiuen
(base) Victorie / and as a Conquerour to lyuen
(base) Noght greueth vs youre glorie / and youre honour
(base) But we biseken / mercy and socour
(base) Haue mercy on oure wo / and oure distresse
(base) Som drope of pitee / thurgh thy gentillesse
(base) Vpon vs wrecched wommen / lat thow falle
(base) For certes lord / ther is noon of vs alle
(base) That she ne hath been / a duchesse / or a queene
(base) Now be we caytyues / as it is wel seene
(base) Thanked be Fortune / and hir false wheel
(base) That noon estaat assureth to been weel
(base) Now certes lord / to abiden youre persence
(base) Heere in this temple / of the goddesse clemence
(base) We haue been waytynge / al this fourtenyght
(base) Now help vs /lord syth it is in thy myght
(base) ¶ I wrecche / which that wepe and waille thus
(base) Was whilom wyf / to kyng Cappaneus
(base) That starf at Thebes / cursed be the day

div.l: (base) And alle we / that been in this array

(base) And ye shal bothe anoon / vnto me swere
(base) That neuere mo / ye shal my contree dere

(base) I yow foryeue / this trespas euerydel
(base) And they hym sworen / his axing faire and wel

(base) ¶ To speke of roial lynage / and richesse

(base) Ech of yow bothe / is worthy doutelees
(base) To wedden whan tyme is / but nathelees

(base) This is to seyn / she may nat now haue bothe
(base) Al be ye neuere so Ialous / ne so wrothe

div.l: (base) Lo here youre ende / of that I shal deuyse
(base) ¶ My wil is this / for plat conclusioun
(base) Withouten any replicacioun
(base) If that yow liketh / take it for the beste
(base) That euerich of yow / shal goon where hym leste
(base) Frely / withouten raunsoun / or daunger
(base) And this day fifty wykes / fer ne neer
(base) Euerich of yow / shal brynge an hundred knyghtes
(base) Armed for listes / vp at alle rightes
(base) Al redy / to darreyne hire by bataille
(base) And this bihoote I yow / withouten faille
(base) Vpon my trouthe / and as I am a knyght
(base) That wheither of yow bothe / that hath myght
(base) This is to seyn / that wheither he or thou

(base) Sleen his contrarie / or out of lystes dryue
(base) Thanne shal I yeue / Emelye to wyue
(base) To whom that Fortune / yeueth so fair a grace
(base) The lystes / shal I maken in this place
(base) And god so wisly / on my soule rewe
(base) As I shal / euene Iuge been and trewe
(base) Ye shul noon oother ende / with me maken
(base) That oon of yow / ne shal be deed / or taken
(base) And if yow thynketh / this is wel ysayd
(base) Sey youre auys / and holdeth yow apayd
(base) This is youre ende / and youre conclusioun
(base) ¶ Who looketh lightly now / but Palamoun
(base) Who spryngeth vp for ioye / but Arcite
(base) Who koude telle / or who koude it endite
(base) The ioye / that is maked in the place
(base) Whan Theseus / hath doon so fair a grace

(base) And namely the Thebans ofte sythe

(base) ¶ Explicit prima pars
(base) ¶ Incipit pars secunda
(base) The ordinaunce of lystys that Thesyus ordeynyd ⁊and cᵒ
(base) I trowe / men wolde deme it necligence

(base) Of Theseus / that gooth so bisily

div.l: (base) To maken vp the lystes / roially
(base) That swich a noble Theatre / as it was
(base) I dar wel seyn / in this world ther nas
(base) The circuit a myle was aboute
(base) Walled of stoon / and dyched al withoute
(base) Round was the shap / in manere of compas
(base) Ful of degrees / the heighte of sixty paas
(base) That whan a man / was set on o degree

(base) ¶ Estward ther stood a gate / of Marbul whit
(base) Westward / right swich another / in the oposit
(base) And shortly to concluden / swich a place
(base) Was noon in erthe / as in so lite a space
(base) For in the lond / ther was no crafty man
(base) That Geometrye / or Ars metrik kan
(base) Ne purtreyour / ne keruere of ymages
(base) That Theseus / ne yaf mete and wages
(base) The Theatre / for to maken and deuyse
(base) And for to doon / his ryte and sacrifise
(base) He Estward hath / vpon the gate aboue
(base) In worship of venus / goddesse of loue
(base) Doon maad an Auter / and an oratorie
(base) And on the westward / in memorie
(base) Of Mars / he maked hath right swich another
(base) That coste largely / of gold a fother
(base) And Northward / in a touret on the wal
(base) Of Alabastre whit and reed Coral
(base) An oratorie / riche for to see
(base) In worship / of Diane of chastitee
(base) Hath Theseus / doon wroght in noble wise
(base) ¶ But yet hadde I forgeten / to deuyse
(base) The noble keruyng and the purtreitures
(base) The shap / the contenance / and the figures
(base) That weren / in thise oratories thre
(base) ¶ First / in the temple of Venus / mayst thow se
(base) Wroght on the wal / ful pitous to biholde
(base) The broken slepes / and the sykes colde
(base) The sacred teerys / and the waymentynge
(base) The firy strokes / of the desirynge
(base) That loues seruantz / in this lyf enduren

div.l: (base) The othes / that hir couenantz assuren
(base) Plesance / and hope / desir / foolhardynesse
(base) Beautee and youthe / baudrye / richesse
(base) Charmes and force / lesynges / flaterye
(base) Despense / bisynesse / and Ialousye
(base) That wered / of yelowe gooldes a gerland
(base) And a Cokkow / sittyng on hir hand
(base) Festes / Instrumentz / caroles / daunces
(base) Lust and array / and alle the circumstaunces
(base) Of loue / whiche that I rekned / and rekne shal
(base) By ordre / weren peynted on the wal
(base) And mo / than I kan make of mencioun
(base) For soothly / al the Mount of Citheroun
(base) Ther Venus / hath hir principal dwellynge
(base) Was shewed on the wal / in purtreyynge
(base) With al the gardyn / and the lustynesse
(base) Nat was foryeten / the porter ydelnesse
(base) Ne Narcisus the faire / of yoore agon
(base) Ne yet the folie / of kyng Salomon
(base) The enchauntement of medea and hardynesse
(base) Of Iason I wil not now expresse
(base) Ne yet the grete strengthe of Ercules
(base) The enchantementz / of Medea and Circes
(base) Ne of Turnus / with the hardy fiers corage
(base) The ryche Cresus / caytif in seruage
(base) ¶ Thus may ye seen / that wisdom ne richesse
(base) Beautee / ne sleighte / strengthe hardynesse
(base) Ne may with venus / maken champartie
(base) For as hir lust the world than may she gye
(base) Lo al this folk so caught were in hir laas
(base) Til they for wo / ful ofte seyde allas
(base) Suffiseth heere ensamples / oon or two
(base) And though / I koude rekne a thousand mo
(base) ¶ The statue of Venus / glorious for to see
(base) Was naked / fletyng in the large See
(base) And fro the nauele doun / al couered was
(base) With wawes grene / and brighte as any glas
(base) A Citole in hir right hand / hadde she
(base) And on hir heed / ful semely for to se
(base) A rose gerland / fressh / and wel smellynge
(base) Aboue hir heed / hir dowues flikerynge
(base) Biforn hire stood / hir sone Cupido
(base) Vpon his shuldres / wynges hadde he two

div.l: (base) And blynd he was / as it is ofte seen
(base) A bowe he bar / and Arwes brighte and keene
(base) ¶ Why sholde I nat as wel / eek telle yow al
(base) The purtreyture / that was vpon the wal
(base) With Inne the temple / of myghty Mars the rede
(base) Al peynted was the wal / in lengthe and brede
(base) Lyk to the eestres / of the grisly place
(base) That highte the grete temple / of Mars in Trace
(base) In thilke colde / frosty Regioun
(base) Ther as Mars / hath his souereyn mansioun
(base) ¶ First on the wal / was peynted a Forest
(base) In which ther dwelleth / neither man ne best
(base) With knotty / knarry / bareyne trees olde
(base) Of stubbes sharpe / and hidouse to biholde
(base) In which / ther ran a rombul / in a swough
(base) As thogh a storm / sholde bresten euery bough
(base) And downward on an hil / vnder a bente
(base) Ther stood the temple / of Mars Armypotente
(base) Wroght al of burned steel / of which the entree
(base) Was long and streyt and gastly for to see
(base) And ther out cam a rage / and swich a veze
(base) That it made / al the gate for to rese
(base) The Northren light in at the dores shoon
(base) For wyndow on the wal / ne was ther noon
(base) Thurgh which men myghten / any light discerne
(base) The dore was al / of Athamant eterne
(base) Yclenched / ouerthwart and endelong /
(base) With Iren togh / and for to make it strong
(base) Euery piler / the temple to sustene
(base) Was tonne greet of Iren bright and shene
(base) ¶ Ther say I first. the dirke ymagynynge
(base) Of felonye / and al the compassynge
(base) The cruel Ire / reed as any gleede
(base) The pike purs / and eek the pale drede
(base) The smylere / with the knyf vnder the cloke
(base) The shipne brennyng with the blake smoke
(base) The tresoun / of the mordryng in the bed
(base) The open werre / with woundes al bibled
(base) Contek with blody knyf and sharp manace
(base) Al ful of chirkyng was that sory place
(base) ¶ The sleere of hymself / yet saugh I ther

div.l: (base) His herte blood / hath bathed al his heer
(base) The nayl ydryuen / in the shode a nyght
(base) The colde deeth / with mouth gapyng vp right
(base) Amyddes of the temple / sat meschaunce
(base) With disconfort and sory contenaunce
(base) ¶ Yet saugh I woodnesse / laughyng in his rage
(base) Armed compleynt out hees / and fiers outrage
(base) The caroyne in the bussh / with throte ycorue
(base) A thousand slayn / and noght of qualm ystorue
(base) The tiraunt with the praye / by force yraft
(base) The town destroyed / ther was no thyng laft
(base) ¶ Yet saugh I brent. the shippes hoppesteres
(base) The hunte strangled / with the wilde beres
(base) The hunt strangled with wilde bores corage
(base) The Sowe freten the child / right in the Cradel
(base) The Cook yscalded / for al his longe ladel
(base) ¶ Naught was forgeten / by the Infortune of Marte
(base) The Cartere / ouer ryden / with his Carte
(base) Vnder the wheel / ful lowe he lay adown
(base) Ther were also / of Martes deuysioun
(base) The Barbour / and the Bochier and the Smyth
(base) That forgeth sharpe swerdes / on his styth
(base) ¶ And al aboue / depeynted in a tour
(base) Saugh I Conquest sittyng in greet honour
(base) With the sharpe swerd / ouer his heed
(base) Hangynge / by a subtil twynes threed
(base) ¶ Depeynted was / the slaghtre of Iulius
(base) Of grete Nero / and of Anthonius
(base) Al be / that thilke tyme / they were vnborn
(base) Yet was hir deeth / depeynted ther biforn
(base) By manacynge of Mars / right by figure
(base) So was it shewed / in that purtreyture
(base) As is depeynted / in the Sertres aboue
(base) Who shal be slayn / or ellis deed for loue
(base) Suffiseth oon ensample / in stories olde
(base) I may nat rekne hem alle / thogh I wolde
(base) ¶ The Statue of Mars / vpon a Carte stood
(base) Lyke vnto the figure of vigynys
(base) Armed / and loked grym / as he were wood
(base) And ouer his heed / ther shynen two figures
(base) Of sterres / that been clepyd in Scriptures
(base) That oon Puella / that oother Rubeus
(base) This god of armes / was arrayed thus

div.l: (base) A wolf ther stood / bifore hym at his feet
(base) With eyen rede / and of a man he eet
(base) With subtil pencel / was depeynted this storie
(base) In redoutynge of Mars / and of his glorie
(base) ¶ Now to the temple / of Diane the chaste
(base) As shortly as I kan / I wol me haste
(base) To telle yow / al the discripsioun
(base) Depeynted been the walles / vp and doun

(base) Ther saw I. / how woful Calistopee
(base) Whan that Diane / agreued was with here

(base) Thus was it peynted / I kan seye yow no ferre
(base) That shynyth in the hevy / frōm yow so ferre
(base) Hir sone is eek a sterre / as men may see
(base) Ther saw I Dane / yturned to a tree
(base) I mene nat / the goddesse Diane
(base) But Penneus doghter / which that highte Dane
(base) ¶ Ther saw I Attheon / an hert ymaked
(base) For vengeaunce / that he saw Diane al naked
(base) I seigh / how that hise houndes haue hym caught
(base) And freten hym / for that they knewe hym naught
(base) ¶ Yet peynted was / a litel ferther moor
(base) How Atthalante / hunted the wilde boor
(base) And Meleagree / and many another mo
(base) For which Diane / wroghte hym care and wo
(base) Ther saw I. many another wonder storie
(base) The whiche / me list nat drawen to memorie
(base) ¶ This goddesse on hert ful hye seet
(base) With smale houndes / al aboute hir feet
(base) And vnder nethe hir feet. she hadde a moone
(base) Wexinge it was / and sholde wanye soone
(base) In gaude grene / hir statue yclothed was
(base) With bowe in honde / and arwes in a cas

(base) Ther Pluto / hath his dirke Regioun
(base) A womman trauailyng was hir biforn

(base) Ful pitously / lucina gan she calle
(base) And seyde help / for thow mayst best of alle

div.l: (base) With many a floryn / he the hewes boghte
(base) ¶ Now been thise listes maad / and Theseus

(base) ¶ The day approcheth / of hir retournynge
(base) That euerich / sholde an hundred knyghtes brynge
(base) The bataille to darreyne / as I yow tolde

(base) Ye knowen wel / that euery lusty knyght /
(base) That loueth paramours / and hath his myght
(base) Were it in Engelond / or ellis where
(base) They wolde hir thankes / wilnen to be there
(base) To fighten for a lady / benedicitee
(base) It were a lusty sighte / for to see
(base) ¶ And right so / ferden they with Palamon
(base) With hym ther wenten / knyghtes many oon
(base) Som wol ben armed / in an haubergeoun
(base) And in a Brestplate / and in a light gypoun
(base) And som wol haue / a peire plates large
(base) And some willen haue a pruce schelde othir targe
(base) And som wol haue / a Pruce sheeld / or a targe
(base) Som wol been armed / on his legges weel
(base) And haue an Ax / and som a Maas of steel
(base) Ther nys no newe gyse / that it nas oold
(base) Armed were they / as I haue yow toold
(base) Euerich / after his opinyoun
(base) ¶ Ther maystow seen / comynge with Palamoun

div.l: (base) Lygurge hymself the grete kyng of Trace
(base) Blak was his beerd / and manly was his face
(base) The cercles of his eyen / in his heed
(base) They gloweden / bitwixen yelow and reed
(base) And lyk a griffoun / loked he aboute
(base) With keempe herys / on his browes stoute
(base) His lymes grete / his brawnes / harde and stronge
(base) Hys shuldres brode / hise armes rounde and longe
(base) And as the gyse was / in his contree
(base) Ful hye / vpon a Chaar of gold stood he
(base) With foure white Boles / in the trays
(base) In stide of Cotearmure / ouer his harnays
(base) With nayles yelwe / and brighte as any gold
(base) He hadde a Berys Skyn / colblak / for old
(base) His longe heer / was kembed bihynde his bak
(base) As any Rauenes fethere / it shoon for blak
(base) A wrethe of gold / greet of huge wighte
(base) Vpon his heed / and ful of stones brighte
(base) Of fyne Rubyes / and of dyamauntz
(base) Aboute his Chaar / ther wente white Alauntz
(base) Twenty and mo / as grete as any steer
(base) To hunten at the leoun / and the deer
(base) And folwed hym / with mosel faste ybounde
(base) Colered of gold / and turrettes filed rounde
(base) An hundred lordes / hadde he in his route
(base) Armed ful wel / with hertes stierne and stoute
(base) ¶ With Arcita / in stories as men fynde
(base) The grete Emetrius / the kyng of Inde
(base) Vpon a Steede bay / trapped in steel
(base) Couered in a clooth of gold / dyapred weel
(base) Cam ridynge / lyk the god of Armes Mars
(base) His cote armure / was of clooth of Tars
(base) Couched with perlys white / and rounde and grete
(base) His sadel was / of brend gold newe ybete
(base) A Mantelet vpon his shulder hangynge
(base) Bretful of Rubies reede / as fyr sparklynge
(base) His crispe heer / lyk rynges was yronne
(base) And that was yelow / and glitred as the sonne
(base) His nose was heigh / hise eyen bright Citryn
(base) His lyppes rounde / his colour was sangwyn
(base) A fewe fraknes / in his face yspreynd

div.l: (base) Bitwixen yelow / and som del blak ymeynd
(base) And as a leoun / he his lookyng caste
(base) Of . xxv. yeer / his age I caste
(base) His beerd / was wel bigonne for to sprynge
(base) His voys / was as a trompe thonderynge
(base) Vpon his heed / he wered of laurer grene
(base) A gerland fressh / and lusty for to seene
(base) Vpon his hand / he bar for his deduyt
(base) An Egle tame / as any lilie whyt
(base) An hundred lordes / hadde he with hym there
(base) Al armed saue hir heddes / in al hir gere
(base) Ful richely / in alle manere thynges
(base) For trusteth wel / that dukes / Erles / kynges
(base) Were gadred / in this noble compaignye
(base) For loue / and for encrees of chiualrye
(base) Aboute this kyng ther ran on euery part
(base) Ful many a tame leoun and leopart
(base) ¶ And in this wise / thise lordes alle and some
(base) Been on the Sonday / to the Citee come
(base) Aboute pryme / and in the town alight
(base) ¶ This Theseus / this duc this worthy knyght
(base) Whan he hadde broght hem / in to his Citee
(base) And Inned hem / euerich at his degree
(base) He festeth hem / and dooth so gret labour
(base) To esen hem / and doon hem al honour
(base) That yet men wenen / that no mannes wit
(base) Of noon estaat ne koude amenden it /
(base) ¶ The Mynstralcye / the seruyce / at the feeste
(base) The grete yiftes / to the meeste and leeste
(base) The ryche array / of Theseus Paleys
(base) Ne who sat first or last vpon the deys
(base) What ladyes fairest been / and best daunsynge
(base) Or which of hem / kan daunse best and synge
(base) Ne who moost feelyngly / speketh of loue
(base) What haukes sitten / on the perche aboue
(base) What houndes lyggen / on the floor adown
(base) Of al this / make I now no mencioun
(base) But al theffect that thynketh me the beste
(base) Now comth the point and herkneth if yow leste
(base) ¶ The Sonday nyght er day bigan to sprynge
(base) Whan Palamon / the larke herde synge

div.l: (base) Althogh it nere nat day / by houres two
(base) Yet soong the larke / and Palamon right tho
(base) Vnto the temple purposeth he to go
(base) With holy herte / and with an heigh corage
(base) He roos / to wenden on his pilgrymage
(base) Vnto the blisful / Scitherea benygne
(base) I mene Venus / honurable and digne
(base) And in hir hour / he walketh forth a paas
(base) Vnto the lystes / ther hir temple was
(base) And down he kneleth / and with humble cheere
(base) And herte soor / he seyde as ye shal heere
(base) ¶ Faireste of faire / o lady myn Venus
(base) Doghter of Ioue / and spouse to Vulcanus
(base) Thow gladere / of the mount of Cytheron
(base) For thilke loue / thow haddest to Adoon
(base) Haue pitee / of my bittre teerys smerte
(base) And taak myn humble prayere at thyn herte
(base) ¶ Allas I ne haue no langage to telle
(base) Theffect. ne the tormentz of myn helle
(base) Myn herte / may myne harmes nat biwreye
(base) I am so confus / that I kan noght seye
(base) But mercy lady bright that knowest wele
(base) My thoght and seest what harmes that I feele
(base) Considre al this / and rewe vpon my soore
(base) As wisly / as I shal for euere moore
(base) Emforth my myght thy trewe seruant be
(base) And holden werre / alwey with chastitee
(base) That make I myn avow / so ye me helpe
(base) I kepe noght of armes for to yelpe
(base) Ne I ne axe noght to morwe / to haue victorie
(base) Ne renoun in this cas / ne veyne glorie
(base) Of prys of armes / blowen vp and down
(base) But I wolde haue / fully possessioun
(base) Of Emelye / and dye in thy seruyse
(base) Fynd thow the manere / how / and in what wyse
(base) I recche nat but it may bettre be
(base) To haue victorie of hem / or they of me
(base) So that I haue / my lady in myn armes
(base) For thogh so be / that Mars is god of armes
(base) Youre vertu is so greet in heuene aboue

(base) Arcite / vnto the temple walked is

(base) And euere mo / vn til that day I dye
(base) Eterne fyr / I wol bifore thee fynde

(base) My berd / myn heer / that hangeth long adown

div.l: (base) That neuere yet ne felte offensioun

(base) My cours / that hath so wyde for to turne

She blissith ⁊and wit ful pitous voys
Vnto þe croys of crist thus seide she
O clere o welful auter holy crois
Rede of þe lambes blood ful of pite
That wisshe the world fro þe olde iniquite
Me fro þe fend ⁊and fro his clawes kepe
That day þat I shal drenchen in þe depe
Victorious tre proteccoıı̄un of trewe
That only worthi were forto bere
The kyng of heuene wit his woundes newe
The white lambe þat hurte was wit a spere hf L
Thorugh payens that conquereden here abowte
The plages of the North by land and see
To Wales fledde þe Cristianyte
Of olde Bretoıı̄uns dwellynge in þis Isle
Ther was hir̉e refuyt for þe mene while
But yit nas neủere cⁱstene Bretoıı̄uns so exiled
That ther nas sōmme in her̉e pⁱriuyte
Honoᵘured cⁱst and hethen folk bigiled
And neygh þe Castell such ther dwelledēn thre
That on of hem was blynde ⁊and mighte nat see
But it were wit þilke eyen of his mynde
With whiche men sen after þat þei ben blynde
¶ Bright was þe sonne as in þat somes day
For which the constable and his wif also
And custance haıı I take þe righte way
To ward þe see a forlong wey or two
To pleyen ⁊and to Romen to and fro
And in hire walk þre blynde men þe mette
Croked ⁊and olde wit faste eyen I shette
¶ In þe name of crist criede this blynde bretoıı̄un
Dame hermengild yeue me sight agayn
This lady wax affrayed of þe sown
Lest þat hire husbond shortly forto seyn
Wolde hire for ihu cristes loue haue slayn
Til Custance made hire bold ⁊and bad hir̉e werche
The wil of Crist as doughter of his cherche
¶ The constable wax a basshed of þat sight
And saide what amonteth al þis fare
Custance answere sire it is cristes might
That helpeth folk out of þe fendes snare
And so ferforth she gan oure lady declare
That she þe constable or þat it was Eue
Cōnuerteþ and on crist made him by leue
¶ This constable was no thing lord of þis place
Of which I speke ther he Custance fonde
But kept it strongly many a wynter space
Vnder alla kyng9 of alle Northumburlande
That was ful wys and worthi of his hande
A gayn þe Scottes as men may wel here
But torne I wil a gayn to my matere
¶ Sathan þat eủere vs wayteth to be gile
Saugh of Custance al hire ꝑperfeccion
And cast anon how he mighte quite hire while
And made a yonge knight þat dwelte in þe toıı̄un
Loue hir so hoot of fowl affeccioıı̄un
That verrely him þoughte he shulde spille
But he of hir mighte ones haue his wille
¶ He woweth hir̉e but it a vailleth nought
She wolde do no synne be no weye
And for dispyt he compassed in his thought
To make hire on shameful deth to deye
He wayteth whan þe constable was a weye
And pⁱriuyly vp on a nyght he crept
In hermengildes chambre while she slept
¶ Wery for waked in hire orisons
Slepeth Custance and hermengild also
This knyght thurgh Sathanas temptacoıı̄uns
Al softely is to þe bedde I go
And kut þe þrote of hermengild a two
And leyde þe blody knyf bi dame Custance
And wente his wey þer god yeue him meschance
¶ Soone after comth þis constable hom a gayn
And ek Alla þat kyng was of þat lond
And saugh his wyf dispitousliche I slayn
For which ful ofte he wept ⁊and wrong his hond
And in the bed þe blody knyf he fond
Bi dame custance allas what mighte she seye
For verrey wo hir witt was al a weye
¶ To kyng Alla was told al þis meschance
And ek þe tyme ⁊and wheer and in what wise
That in a shipp was fonden this Custance
As here be forn ye haıı herd eer̉e deuise
The kynges herte of pite gan a grise
Whan he sey so benigne acreature
Falle in disease and in mysauenture
¶ For as þe lomb to ward his deth is brought
So stant þis Innocent bi fore the kyng
This fals knyght þat hath þis trayson wrought
Berith hire an hand þat she hath do þis thing
But natheles þer was gret mornyng
A mong þe poeple and sey þei can not gesse
That she hadde don so gret a wikkedenesse
The fruyt of eủery tale is forto seie
þe ete and drink and dance and synge ⁊and pleye
¶ Thei gon to bedde as it was skil and right
For þough þat wyfes ben ful holy thinges
Thei moste take a pacience anyght
Such mane necessaries as ben plesynges
To folk þat haıı y wedded hem wit rynges
And leye a lite hir holynesse a side
As for þe tyme it may non oþer be tyde
¶ On hire he gate a knaue child a non
And to a Bisshop ⁊and his constable eke
He took his wyf to kepe whan he is gon
To Scotlond ward his fomēn forto seke
Now faire Custance þat is so humble ⁊and meke
So long is gon with child til þat stille
She halt hire chambre abidinge at cⁱstes wille
¶ The tyme is come a knaue child she bere
Mauricius atte fontston þei him calle
This constable doth forth come a messager̉e
And wrot to his kyng þat clepid was Alle
How þat þis blisful tydyng9 is by falle
And oþer tydynges spedful for to seye
He tath þe letter ⁊and forth he goth his weye
¶ This messager to don his auantage
Vn to þe kynges moder rideth swithe
And salueth hire ful faire in his langage
Ma dame qd he ye may be glad ⁊and blithe
And thonketh god an hundred þousande sythe
Mi lady queen hath childe wit oute doute
To Ioye and blisse of alle þis regne a boute
¶ Lo here þe lres seled of þis thing
That I mote bere wit al þe hast y may
If ye wil aught vnto ȝoure sone þe kyng
I am youre seruant boþe nyght and day
Dongild answerd as now at þis tyme nay
But here al night I wil þat þᵘ take þi rest
To morwe wil I sey what me lest
¶ This messanger drank sadly ale and wyn
And stolen weren his lres pⁱriuely
Out of his box whil he sleep as a swyn
And contirfetid was ful subtilly
An other lre wrought ful synfully
Vn to þe kyng direct of this matere
For his conestlible as ye shal after here
¶ The lre spak þe quene deliủered was
Of so horrible a fendlich creature
That in þe castell non so hardy was
That ony while dorste þ̉ere In endure
The moder was an Elf bi auenture
Y come by charmes or bi sorcerie
And eủery wight hateth hire companye
¶ Wo was þis kyng whan he þis lre hadde seyn
But to no wight he tolde his sorwes sore
But of his oune hond he wrot a geyn
Welcome þe sonde of crist for eủere more
To me þat am now lerned in his lore
Lord welcome be þi lust ⁊and thi plesance
My lust is put al in þin ordinance
¶ Kepeth þis child al be it foul or faire
And ek my wyf vnto myn hom comyng
Crist whan him list may sende me an ayre
More agreable þan þis is to my lykynge
This lre he seleth pⁱriuely wepyng
Which to þe messager was take sone
And forth he goth þer is no more to done
¶ O messager fulfild of dronkenesse
Strong is þi breth þi lymes faltren ay
And þu bi wreyest alle sykernesse
Thi mynde is lorn þu Ianglest as a iay
Thi face is tourned in an newe array
Ther dronkenesse regneth in ony rowte
Ther nys no conseil hid wit oute doute
O Donegild I ne haue no englisshe digne
Vnto þi malice and þi tyrannye
And þerfore to þe fend I þe resigne
Lat him enditen of thi traiterie
Fy mānnysshfy o nay bi god I lye
Fy fendlich sꝑperit for I dar wel telle
Thow þᵘ here walke þi sꝑperit is in helle
¶ This messager comeþ fro þe kyng a gayn
And at þe kynges moderes court he lighte
And she was of þis messager ful fayn
Habundantly for hir ful longe space
And oþer necessaries þat sholde nede
She hadde I nowe heryed be goddes grace
For wynd and weder almyghty god pʳchace
And brynge hir hom y kan no bett̉er sey
But in þe see she dryueth forth hir wey
¶ Alla the kyng comth hom sone after þis
Vn to his castell of þe which I tolde
And axeth wher his wif ⁊and his child is
The constable gan a bowte his herte colde
And pleynly al the manere he him tolde
As ye haıı herd y kan telle it no bettre
And sheweth the kyng his seal ⁊and his lettre
¶ And seide lord as ye comanded me
Vp peyne of deth so haue I doon c̉erteyn
This messager tormented was til he
Moost bi knowen and tellen plat ⁊and pleyn
From nyght to nyght in what place he had leyn
And thus bi wit and subtil enqueryng
Ymagyned was bi whom þis harm gan spryng
¶ The hond was knowen that the lre wroot
And alle þe venym of this cursed dede
But in what wyse certeynly I noot
The effect is this that Alla out of drede
His moder slow þat may men pleynly rede
For that she traytour was to hir legeance
Thus endeth olde Donegild wit meschaıı̄unce
¶ The sorwe that this Alla nyght and day
Maketh for his wyf and for his child also
Ther is no tunge þat it telle may
But now wil I vnto Custance go
That fleteth in þe see in peyne ⁊and woo
V yer and more as lykede cⁱstes sonde
Or that hir ship Approchede vnto londe
¶ Vnder an hethen castell atte laste
Of which the name in my text nouȝt y fynde
Custance and ek hir child þe see vp cast
Almyghty god that saueth al mankynde
Haue on custance and hir child som mynde
That fallen is in hethen hond eft sone
In poynt to spille as I schal telle yow sone
¶ Down fro þe castel comth ther many a wight
To gawren on þis ship and on Custance
But shortly fro the castel on a nyght
The lordes styward god yeue hym meschance
A theef that hadde renyed oure cʳance
Come in to ship allone and seide he sholde
Hir lēmman be wher so she wolde or nolde
¶ Wo was this wrecchede wōmman tho bi gon
Hir child cⁱede and she criede pitously
But blisful marie halp hir riȝt a noon
For with hire strogeling wel and myghtily
The thef fel ouer bord al sodeynly
And in þe see he dreynt for vengeance
And thus hath criste vnwemmed kept custance
O fowl lust of luxurie lo thyn ende
Nat only that þu fayntest mānnes mynde
But verreyly thow wolt his body shende
The ende of þi werke or of thi lustes blynde
Is compleynyng how many oon may men fynde
That nought for werk som tyme but for thentent
To don this synne ben eyther slayn or shent
¶ How may this weyk wōmman haıı the strengthe
Hire to defende a geyn this renegat
O golyas vn mesurable of lengthe
How might Dauid make the so mat
So yonge and of Armure so desolat
How dorst he loke vp on thi dredful face
Wel may men seen it was but goddꝭes grace
¶ Who yaf Iudith corage or hardynesse
To slen him Olefernus in his tent
And to delyuerēn owt of wrechedenesse
The peple of god I sey for this entent
That right as god sꝑperit and vigor sent
To hem and saued hem out of meschance
So sent he myght and vigor to custance
¶ Forth goth hir ship thorw on the narwe mouth
Of Iubaltar and septe dryuyng Ay
Som tyme west and somtyme north ⁊and south
And som tyme est ful many a wery day
Til cristes moder blessid be she ay
Hath shapen thorugh hire endeles goodnesse
To make an ende of al hire heuynesse
¶ Now late vs stynte of custance but a throwe
And speke we of the Romeyn Emꝑperour
That owt of Surrye hath be lettres knowe
The slaughtere of cⁱstene folk and deshonoᵘur
Don to his doughter by a fals traytour
I mene the cursede wikkede sowdonesse
That at the feste let slen bothe more ⁊and lesse
¶ For which þis Emꝑperour hath sent anon
His senatour wit real ordinance
And oþer lordes god wot mony on
On surreyens to taken hey vengeance
Thei brennen slen and bryngen hem to meschance
Ful many a day but shortly this is thende
Homward to Rome they shapen hem to wende
¶ This senatour repayreth with victorye
To Romeward sailing ful really
And mette þe shipp dryuyng as seith the storye
In whiche Custance sitt ful pitously
No thing ne knew he what she was ne whi
She was in such array ne she nyl seye
Of hir estat though she sholde deye
¶ He bryngeth hire to Rome and to his wif
He yaf hire and hire yonge sone also
And with þe senatour she lad hir lyf
Thus kan oure lady bringen out of wo
Woful custance and many an other mo
And long tyme dwelled she in that place
In holy werkes euere as was hir grace
¶ The senatours wif hire aunte was
But for al that she knewe hire neuere þe more
I wil no lenger tarien in this cas
But to kyng Alla which I spak of yore
That for his wyf wepith ⁊and siketh sore
I wil retorne and lete I wil custance
Vnder þe senatour9 goủernance
¶ Kyng Alla which þat hadde his moder slayn
Vp on aday fil in such repentance
That yif I shortly tellen shal ⁊and playn
To Rome he cometh to receyuen his penance
And put him in the popes ordinance
In by an low and Ihu crist be soughte
For yeue his wikkede werkes þat he wroughte
¶ The fame anon thorow Rome town is born
How Alla kyng shal comen In pilgrymage
Bi herberiours that wenten him bi forn
For which the senatour as was vsage
Rod him a geyn and many of his lynage
As wel to shewen his hie magnificence
As to don any kyng a Reuerence
¶ Gret cher doth this noble senatour
To kyng Alla and he to him also
Euerich of hem doth other gret honour
And so bi fil þat in a day or two
This senatour is to kyng alla go
To feste ⁊and shortly yif I shal not lye
Custance sone in his companye
¶ Som men wolde seyn atte requeste of custance
This senatour hath lad this child to feste
I may not tellen eủerych cⁱcıı̄unstance
Be as be may þer was he atte leste
But soth is this that at his moderes heste
By forn Alla duryng þe metes space
The child stod lokyng in the kyng9 face
¶ This Alla kyng hath of the child gret wondir
And to the senatour he saide anon
Whos is that faire child þat stondeth yonder
I not qd he be god and be seynt Iohn
A moder he hath but fader hath he non
That I of woot and shortly in a stounde
He tolde Alla how that this child was founde
¶ But god woot qd this senatour also
So vertuous a lyuere in my lyf
Ne saw I neuere as she ne herde of mo
Of worldly wōmmen / mayde ne of wyf
I dar wel sayn she hadde leuer a knyf
Thorw out hire brest than ben a wōmman wykke
Ther is no man kowthe brynge hir to þat prikke
Now was þis childe as lyk vn to custance
As possible as is a creature to be
This Alla hath þe face in Remēmbrance
Of dame custance and þer on mused he
Yf that þe childes moder were aught she
That is his wif and pⁱriuely he sighte
And spedde him fro the table that he myghte
¶ ꝑperfay he thought þe fantome is in myn hed
I owght demen of skilful Iuggement
That in þe salt see my wif is ded
And afterward he made his argument
What woot I yif þat crist hath hider sent
My wif be see as wel as he hir sente
To my contre fro thennes þat she was wente
¶ And after anon hom with the senatour
Goth Alla for to sen this wonder chance
This senatour doth Alla gret honour
And hastisly he sente after custance
But trusteth wel hire lust nought to daunce
Whan þᵗat she wiste wher fore was that sonde
Vnnethe vp on hir feet she myghte stonde
¶ Whan Alla saugh his wif faire he hire grette
And wepte þat it was reuthe for to se
For atte ferst loke he on hir sette
He knew wel verrely that it was she
And for sorwe as domb stant as a tre
So was hir herte shet in hir distresse
Whan she remembred his vnkyndenesse
¶ Twies she swowneth in his owne sighte
He wepe and him excuseth pitously
Now god qd he and his halewes bright
So wisly on my sowle as haue mercy
That of yowre harm as giltles am I
As is Maurice my sone so lyk yowre face
Elles the fende me fecche owt of this place
¶ Longe was the sobbynge and þe bittere peyne
Or that hir woful hertes might cesse
Gret was the pite for to here hem pleyne
Thorugh which pleyntes gan hir wo encresse
I pray yow alle my labour to relesse
I may not tellen hir wo vntil to morwe
I am so wery for to speke of here sorwe
¶ But fynaly whan þat þe sothe is wiste
That Alla giltles was of hir wo
I trowe an C tymes ben thei kiste
And such a blisse is ther bi twixe hem two
That saue the ioye that lasteth euere mo
Ther is non lyke that ony creature
Hath seyn or shall while þe werld may dure
¶ Tho preyede she hir housbonde mekely
In relief of hire longe pitous pyne
That he wolde pray hir fadir specialy
That of his mageste he wolde enclyne
To fowche sauf som day wit him to dyne
She preyede him ek he sholde be no weye
Vn to hire fadir no word of hire seye
Som men wolde seyn how that the child Maurice
Doth this message vn til this Emꝑperour
But as I gesse Alla was nought so nyce
To him þat was of so soủereigne honour
As he that is of cⁱstene folk þe flour
Sent any child but it is bet to deme
He went him self and so it may wel seme
¶ This Emꝑperour hath gᵃunted gentilly
To come to dyner as he him bi sought
And wel rede I he lokede bisyly
Vp on this child And on his doughter thought
Alla goth to his In and as him ought
Arraied for this feste in euery wyse
As ferforth as his connynge may suffise
¶ The morwe com ⁊and Alla gan him dresse
And ek his wyf this Emꝑperour forto mete
And forth thei ride in ioye ⁊and in gladnesse
And whan she say hir fader in the strete
She lighte adown and fallith him to fete
Fadir qd she youre yonge child custance
Is now ful clene owt of yowre remembᵃnce
¶ I am yowre doughter Custance qd she
That whilom ye sent vn to surrye
It am I fader that in the salt see
Was put allone and dampned for to dye
Now good fadir now I yow mercy crye
Send me no more vn to non hethenesse
But thonk my lord here of his kyndenesse
¶ Who can the pitous ioye tellen al
Bitwix hem thre syn thei ben thus y mette
But of my tale make an ende I shal
The day goth faste I wil no lengere lette
This glad folk to dyner thei hem sette
In ioye and blisse at mete I lete hem dwelle
A thousand fold wel more þan I can telle
¶ This child Maurice was sithen Emꝑperour
Made by the pope and lyuede cristyenly
To crist9 chirche he did gret honour
But I lete al his story passen by
Of custance is my tale specialy
In olde Romeyn gestes men may fynde
Maurices lyf I bere it nought in mynde
¶ This king Alla whan he his tyme say
With his custance his holy wif so swete
To Englond be thei come the right way
Where as thei lyue in ioye and in quyete
But litel while it lasteth I yow hete
Ioye of this werld for tyme wil nought abide
Fro day to nyght it chaungeth as the tyde
Who lyued euere in swich delyt aday
That ne meued eyther conscience
Or ire or talent of som kyn affray
Enuye or pryde or passion or offence
I ne say but for this ende this sentence
That litel whil in ioye or in plesance
Lasteth the blisse of Alla with Custance
For deth that taketh of hiegh ⁊and lough his rent
Whan passed was a yer Euene as y gesse
Owt of this world this kyng Alla he hent
For whom Custance hath ful gret heuynesse
Now lat vs prayen god his soule blesse
And dame Custance finaly to seye
Toward the town of Rome goth here weye
To Rome is come this holy creature
And fyndeth hir frende hol and sounde
Now is she scaped al hir̉e auenture
And whan she hir̉e fadir hath I founde
Down on hir knes falleth she to grounde
Wepynge for tendirnesse in herte blithe
She herieth god an C thousand sithe
¶ In v̉ertue ⁊and holy almesdede
Thei lyuen alle and neủere a sondre wende
Til deth deꝑparte hem this lyf thei lede
And fareth now wel my tale is at an ende
Now Ihu crist that of his myght may sende
Ioye after woo gouerne vs in his grace
And kepe vs alle that ben in this place

Here begynnyth the ꝓprolog of the clerke of Oxenford
SIre clerk of Oxenford oure ost saide
Ye ryde as stille as coy as doth a mayde
Were newe spoused sittyng at a bord
This day ne herde I of your mouthe a word
I trowe þat ye studye a boute som sophyme
But salomon seyth al thyng hath tyme
For godes sake beth of bett̉er chere
It is no tyme now to stodye here
Telle vs som mery tale by youre fay
For what man is entred in to a play
He nedes mot in to þat play assente
But prechith nowht as freres don in lente
To make for oure olde synnes to weepe
Ne þat þi tale ne make vs nowht to sleepe
Tell vs som mery thyng of auentures
Youre termes youre figures and your coloures
Keepe hem in store til so be ye hem endyte
Heygh stile as when men to kynges wryte
Speketh so playn at this tyme I yow pray
That we may vnderstonde what ye say
This worthy clerk benyngnely answerde
Oste quod he I am vnder youre yerde
Ye haue as now of vs þe goủernaunce
And þer fore wol I do yow obeysaunce
As fer as resoun asketh hardyly
I wol yow telle a tale whyche þat I
Lerned at Padow of a worthy clerk
As proued by hyse wordes and by his werk
He is now ded and nayled in his cheste
I pray to god so seende his soule good reste
Fraunceys Ptrak the laureol poete
Hyght this clerk whos retoryk swete d
Enlemyneth al ytayle thurgh poetrye
As lynyan dede of philosophie
Or lawe or other art particuler
But deth that nyl suffere no thyng heere
But as it were twnkelyng of an eye
Bothe hath he slayn and alle shulle we deye
But for to tellen of thys worthi man
That tawght me this tale as I first be gan
I sey that he first wyth heigh style endyteth
Er he the body of his tale wryteth
A prohem in þe whiche discerneth he
Te mounde and of saluces the countre
And speketh of appenyn the hilles heye
That been the boundes of west lumbardye
And of mount vesulus in special
Wher as the poo out of a welle smal
Taketh his first spryngyng and his cours
To emelward to ferrare and to venyse
The whiche a long thing were to deuyse
And trewely as to my Iuggement
Me thynketh it a thing Inꝑpertinent
Saue he wol conueyen his matere
But this is þe tale whiche þat ȝe shullen here
Here endith the prolog / / And begynneth the tale .
THer is at the west syde of ytayll
Doun at þe roote of vesulus the colde
A lusty playn habundant of vitayl
Wher many a toıı̄un thou maist by holde
That founded were in tyme of Elderes olde
And many anoþer dilectable syght
And saluce this noble Conterey hyght
A marquis was whilom in that lond
As were his worthi elderes hym be fore
Thus in delyt he lyued and hath doon yore
By loued and drad thurgh fauour and fortune
Bothe of his lordes and of his comune
Ther with he was as to speke of lynage
The gentelest I born of al lumbardye
A faire ꝑpersone and strong and ȝonge of age
And ful of honoure and of curtesye
Discret I now his contrey for to gye
Saue in som thynges he was to blame
And wateer was this ȝonge lordus name
I blame hym thus that he considered nowght
In tyme comynge what myght betyde
But on his lust psent was al his thowght
And for to hauke and hunte on euery syde
Wel neey al oþer cures let he slyde
And eek he ne wolde that was werst of al
Wedde no wyf for owght that myhte befal
Only that poynt his peple bare so sore
That flok meel on a day they went
And oon of hem þat wisest was of lore
Or elles þat þe lord wold best assente
That he shulde telle hym what his peple mente
Or elles couthe he wel shewe suche matere
He to the marquis sayde as ye mowe here
O noble marquis youre humanyte
Assureth vs and yef vs hardynesse
As ofte tyme as it is necessite
That we ȝow mowe telle oure heuynesse
Accepteth lord of youre gentilnesse
That we to yow with pitous herte complayne
And let youre eres nowght my voys disdeyne
Al haue I nowht to doon in this matere
More than an other hath in this place
Yet for as moche as ye my lord so deere
Han alwey shewed fauour and grace
I dar the bettere aske of yow a space
Of audience to shewen oure requeste
And ye my lord to doon ryght as yow lust
For certes lord so wel vs lyketh yow
And al youre werkes and euere han don that we
Ne couthe nowght our owne self deuysen how
We myghte more lyue in felicite
Saue oon thyng lord yef it youre wille be
That for to be a weddyd man yef yow leste
Than were youre peple in soủerain hertes reste
Boweth ȝoᵘur necke vndir that blisful yok
Of soueraynte nowght of seruyse
Wheche men clepe spousail or wedlok
And thenketh lord among youre thoughtes wyse
For though we slepe or wake roome or ryde
Ay fleeth þe tyme it wol no man abyde
And though youre grene youthe growe as yet
In Crepeth age al way as stil as ston
And deth manaseth euery age and smyt
In ecche estat for there askapeth noon
And also certayn as we knowith eủerychon
That we shulle deye and vncerteyn that we alle
Ben of that day that deth shal on vs falle
Accepteth thanne of vs the trewe entent
That neủere yet refuseth youre heste
And we wolen alle lord yef ye wolen assente
Chese yow a wyf in short tyme at þe leste
Boren of þe genteleste and of þe meste
Of al this lond so that it oute seme
Honoure to god and yow as we can deme
Delyuere vs of al this besy drede
And tak a wyf for heigh godes sake
For yif it be fel so as god for beede
That thurgh deth lynage shulde slake
And a straunge lynage shulde take
Oure heritage oo woo were vs thanne
Wherefore we pray yow hastely to wyfe
Here meek preyer and here pitous chere
Made the marquis haue pite swythe
Wol ye quod he myn oune peple deere
To þat I neuer erst thoughte constreyne me
I me reioiese of my lyberte
That selden tyme is founden in maryage
Ther I was free I mot been in suage
But natheles I see youre trewe entente
And trust vp on yow and haue I doon ay
Wherfore of my fre wil I assente
To wedde me as sone as euer I may
But there as ye han ꝓprofered me to day
To cheese me a wyf I yow relece
That choys and pray yow of that profre sece
For god it woot that children ofte been
Vn lyke or worthi elderes hem by fore
Bounte cometh al of god not of the strene
Of whiche thei been engendred and y bore
I truste in godes bounte and therfore
My maryage and myn estat and reste
I hym be take he may doon as hym luste
Let me allone in chesyng of my wyf
That charge vpon my bak I wol endure
But I yow pray and charge vpon youre lyf
That wyf þᵗat I take ye me ensure
To worschipe hire whil my lyf endure
In word an werk bothe heere and euery where
As she an Emꝑperoures doughter were
And furthermore this shulen ye sweren that ye
A yene my chois shullen neither grucchen ne stryue
For sythe I shal for go my liberte
At youre requeste as euere mote I thryue
There as myn herte is set ther wol I wyfe
And but ye wolen assente in suche maner
I pray yow speketh nomore of this matere
With hertely wil they sworen and assenten
To al this thyng ther sayde no wyht nay
By sechyng hym of grace er thei wenten
That he hem wolde graunte a certeyn day
Of his spousaile as sone as eủere he may
For yit alwey the peple somwhat dredde
Leste this marquis wolde no wyf wedde
He graunted hem a day suche as hym luste
On whoche he wolde be wedded sicurly
And saide he dide al this at here requeste
And thei with humble entent ful buxumly
Kneelyng vpon here knees ful reuerently
Hym thonkyng alle and thus thei han an ende
Of here entent and hoom ayen thei wende
And here vpon he took his officeres
Comaundyng for the feste to purueye
And to hys pryuey knyghtes and sqwyeres
Whiche charge yaf hem as his lust on hem to leye
And thei hise comaundemens to obeye
And ecche of hem doth his bysinesse
To doon vn to þe feste reuerence
Owyht fer from thilke place honorable
Where as this marquis shoop his maryage
There stood a Throp of sighte delittable
In whiche that pore folk of that village
Hadden here bestes and here herbigage
And of here lobour took heere sustenaunce
After þe erthe hem yaf habundaunce
Among this poore folk there dwelled a man
Whiche that was holden porest of hem alle
But heygh god som tyme seende can
His grace vnto alitel oxe stalle
Ianicula men of that throp hym calle
A doughter hadde he faire and yong of sighte
And Grysilde þis yonge mayde highte
But for to speke of v̉ertuous beaute
Than was she oon þe fairest vnder sonne
Wel pouerly I fostred was she
No lykerousnesse was on hir lust I ronne
Wel ofter of þe welle þan of þe tonne
Sche drank and for she wolde v̉ertu plese
Sche knewe wel labour but noon Idel ese
But though þis mayde weere of age
Yit in þe brest of hire virginite
Ther was enclosed ripe and sad corage
And in grete reủerence and gret charite
Hire olde poủere fader fostred sche
A fewe scheep spynnyng on þe feld she kepte
Sche wolde not been Idel til she slepte
And whan she homward come she wolde brynge
Wortes and herbes tymes ful ofte
Whiche she schrad and seth for hire lyuynge
And made hire bed ful hard and no thyng softe
And euer she kepte hire fader lyf on lofte
With euery obeisaunce and diligence
Þat child may do to fadres reuerence
Vpon Grisilde the pore creature
Wel ofte hath markys sette hys eye
As he an huntynge rood ꝑparauenture
And whan it fel þat he myghte hire aspie
He not wiþ wanton lookynge of folye
His eyen cast vpon hire but in sad wyse
Vpon hire cheere he wolde hym ofte avyse
Commendynge yn his herte hire wōmmanheede
And eke hire v̉ertu passyng eny wyght
Of so yonge Age as wel in chere as in dede
For though þe peple han no grete insyght
In vertu he considered ful right
Hire beaute and disposid that he wolde
Hire wedde if euere he wedde sholde
¶ The day of weddyng cam but no wyght can
Telle what wōmman it sholde be
For whiche meruayle wondred many aman
And seiden when þei weere in pryuyte
Wol noght oure lord leue his vanyte
Wil he noght wedde allas allas þe while
Whi wol he hym self and vs thus be gile
¶ But natheles þis markys haþ do make
Of Gemmes set in gold and in azure
Broches and rynges for Grisildes sake
And of hire cloþinge took he þe mesure
Of a mayden lyke to hire stature
And eke of othre ornamentes alle
Þat to suche a weddynge shulde falle
¶ The tyme of vnderne in þe same day
Aprocheth þᵗat þis weddynge shulde be
And al þe Paleys put was in aray
Boþe halle and chambres eche in his degre
Houses of office stuffed with gret plente
There mayst þou see of deyntevous vitaille
That may be founde as fer as lasteth Itayle
¶ This real marquys really arrayed
Lordes and ladyes in hys companye
The whiche to þe feste were prayed
And of hys retenu þe bachelerrye
With many a soıı̄un of sondry melodye
Vn to þe vilage whiche I tolde
In this aray the ryght way haþ holde
¶ Grysylde god woot of þis ful Innocent
Þat for hire was shape al þis array
To Fecchen water at þe welle is went
And cometh home as sone as euere she may
For wel she herde seye þat ilke day
Þat marquys shulde wedde ⁊and if she myghte
Sche wolde fayn see som of þat syght /
¶ Sche þoughte I wole with oþer maydenes stonde
That been my felawes in oure dore and see
The marquys and þerfore wole I fonde
To done at home as sone as it may be
Þe laboure whiche þᵗat longeth to me
And þen may I at leyser it by holde
If þei þis way to þe castel holde
¶ And as she wolde ouer þe thresshefold gon
The markys come and gan hire for to calle
And she sette doun hire water potte anon
Bysyde þe thresshefold of þe oxe stalle
And doun vpon hire knees she gan to falle
And with sad contynaunce knelyd stille
Til she had herd was þe lordes wille
¶ This thoghtful marquys spak vnto þis mayde
Wel soberly and saide in þis manere
Where is youre fader Grysilde he saide
And she with reuerence and meke the chere
Answerede lord he is al reedy heere
And in she goþ with outen ony lenger lette
And to þe markys she hire fader fette
¶ He by þe hond þan toke þis olde man
And saide þus whan he hym hadde aside
Iaincula I neyther may ne can
Lengere þe plesaunce of myn herte hyde
If that þow vouche saf what so be tyde
Thi doughter wole I take or þᵗat I wende
As for my wyf til my lyues ende
¶ Thou louest me I wot wel certeyn
And art my feithful lige man I bore
And al that lykeþ me I dar wel seyn
Hit lykeþ the and specialy þ̉erfore
Telle me þat poynt þat I haue seid byfore
If that þou wolt vn to that purpos drawe
To take me as for thi sone in law /
¶ The sodayn cas þe man astonyed so
Þat reed he wax al basched and al quakynge
He stood vnnethe ne seide wordes mo
But only þus loᵘurrd quod he my willynge

I wol no thyng ye beeþ my lord so dere
Right as yow lest goủerrneth this matere /
Than wole I do thus quod marquys softely
Þat in to þe chambre I ⁊and ye and she

For I wole aske hire if hire wille be

And al this she shal don in þi psence
I wole nought speke out of þyn audience
¶ And in þe chambre while thei were aboute

Þe peeple come in to þe hous wyth oute
And wondred hem in how honest manere
And tentyfly she kepte hire fader dere
But vtterly Grysilde wondre myghte
For neuere erst say she suche a syghte
¶ No wonder is thou she were astonyed
To see so grete agest come in to that place
Sche was neuere to suche gestes woned
For whiche she lokyd with ful pale face
But shortly fro þis matere for to pace
These were þe wordes þat þis markys saide
To this benygne v̉erray feithful mayde
¶ Grysilde he saide ye wole wel vnderstonde

As I suppose þᵗat . ye woleþ þᵗat it so be
But þis demaunde I axe ferst quod he

¶ I seie this be ye reedy wyth good herte
To al my lust and þat I frely may
As me best þinkeþ do yow lawhe or smerte
And ye neủere grucche nyght ne day
And eke whan I seye ȝe seie ye not nay
Neither be word ne froward contynaunce
Swere this and here I swere oure allyaunce
¶ Wondrynge vpon this word quakynge for drede
Sche saide Indigne and vn worthi
Am I to that that ye me beede
But ryght as ye wole yowre self so wole I
And I swere þat neủere wyllyngly
In word ne in thought I neủere yow disobeye d
¶ For to be ded þough me were looth to deye
This is I now Grysilde myn quod he
And forth he goth with a sobre chere
Out at þe dore after cam she
And to þe peeple he saide on þis manere
This is my wyf quod he þat stondeþ here
Honoureth hire and loueþ hire I preye
Who so loueth me þe is nomore to seye
¶ And for no þing of hire olde gere
She shulde brynge to his hous he bad
Þat wōmmen schulde spoylen hyre ryght there
Of whiche þe ladies were not right glad
To handle hire clothes in whiche she was clad
But natheles þis mayde bryght of hiewe
Fro foot to heed I clothed han al newe
¶ Hir heres han thei kembed þat lay vntressed
Wel nudely with hire fyngres smale
A croune on hire heed þe han dressed
And sette hit ful of ouches grete and smale
Of hire array what schuld I make a tale
Vnnethe þe peeple hire knewe for hire fairenesse
Whan she transformed was in suche rychesse
¶ This marquys hath hire spoused with a ryng
Bought for þe same cause and þen hire sette
Vpon an hors snow whyt ⁊and wel amblyng
And to his paleys or he lengere lette
With ioyful peeple þat he lad and mette
Conueied hire and thus þe day þei spende
