¶ And shortly forth þis tale for to chace
I seie þat to þis newe marquyssesse
God hath I sent suche fauour of his gce
Þat it semed not as by lyknesse
That she was born and fed in rudenesse
As in a cote or in an oxe stalle
But norysshed in an Emꝑperours halle
¶ To euery wyght she woxen is so deere
And worshipful þat folk þere she was bore
And fro hire burþe knewe hir fro ȝere to ȝere
Vnnethe trowed þei but dorste haue swore
Þat to Iaincle of whiche I spak byfore
She doughter ne were for as by coniecture
Hem thoughte sche was an oþ̉er creature
¶ For that eủere v̉ertuos was she
Sche was encresed in suche excellence
Of thewes sette in heygh bounte
And so discrete ⁊and faire of eloquence
So benyngne and digne of reuerence
And couthe þe peeple herte so enbrace
That ecche hire loued þᵗat loked on hire face
¶ Nought only of saluce in þe toun
Publisshed was þe bounte of hire name
And eke be syde in many a regioun
If oon saide wel an other saide þe same
So sprad of hire bounte the fame
Þat men and wōmmen boþe yonge and olde
Goon to saluce hire to byholde
¶ This Walt̉er lowely nay but really
Weddeþ with fortune honeste
In goddes pees lyueth wel esyly
At home and outward grace I nowh had he
And for he saw vnder lowe degre
Was ofte v̉ertu hid þe deuel hym held
A prudent man and þat is sene wel seld
¶ Nought only Grysilde þus thurgh hire wit
Coude al þe feet of wyfly homlynesse
But eke whan þe cas required hit
The comune ꝓprofit couthe she redresse
Ther nas discord rancour ne heuynesse
In al þe land þat she ne coude it cese
And brynge hem alle wysely in reste and eese
¶ Though þat hire housbonde psent were or noon
Y gentil men or othir of hire contre
Were wroth she couthe brynge hem attone
So wys and rype wordes had she
And Iuggement of so gret equyte
Þat she fro heuene was as men wende
Peeple to saue and euery wrong to amende
¶ Nought long tyme after þat þis grisilde
Was wedded she a doughter hath I bore d
Al had she leủere han born a knaue childe
Glad was þe marquys ⁊and his folke þ̉erfore
For though a mayden childe come al by fore
She may to a knave childe atteyne
By lyklyhede sethyns sche is not bareyne
¶ Ther fore as hit falleth tymes mo
Whan þis childe hath souked but a throwe
This marquys in hys herte longeth so
To tempte his wif hire sadnesse to knowe
Þat he ne myghte fro his herte throwe
This mueillous desire his wyf to assaye
Natheles god woot he thought hire to affraye
¶ He hadde assaied hire I now by fore
And fond hire eủere good what neediþ hit
Hire forto tormente and alwey more ⁊and more
Though som men preyse hit for a sotel wit
But as for me I seie þat euel hit sit
To assaie a wyf whanne hit is no neede
And putten hire in angwishe and in drede
¶ For whiche þis marquys wroughte on þis mane
He cam anyght alone þ̉ere as she lay
With sterne face and trouble cheere
And saide to Grysilde quod he þat day
Þat I yow toke out of ȝoᵘur poủere array
And put yow in estate of hye noblesse
Ye han not ȝit forȝetyn as I gesse
¶ I saye Grisilde þis psent dignyte
In whiche I haue put yow as I trowe
Maketh you nought forȝitful for to be
That I yow took in poủere estat ful lowe
For eny thyng ȝe mote ȝoure seluen knowe
Take heed of euery word þat I yow say
Þere is no wyght þat heereþ þis but we tway
¶ Ye wote ȝoᵘur self wel how þat ȝe come here
In to þis hous hit is nought longe a goo
And thoughethoughthoughe to me ȝe ben leef and dere
Vn to my genteles ȝe be no thyng soo
Thei seie to hem hit is gret shame ⁊and woo
For to been suget and in ʆseruage
To þe þat art born of so low lynage
¶ And namely sithen þi doughter was bore
These wordes han þei spoke douteles
But I desire as I haue done here byfore
To lyue my lyf with hem in reste ⁊and pees
Imay nought in þis cas been recheles
I moste doon with þi doughter for þe beste
Nought as I wolde but as my gentiles leste
¶ And yit god woot þis is wel loth to me
But natheles with oute youre wrytyngew ytyngewrytynge
I wol not do but þis I wil quod he
That ye to me assente as in thyng
Shewith now youre pacience in ȝoᵘur worchyng
Þat ȝe me be hight and swore in ȝoᵘur village
That day þat maked was oure mariage
¶ What she had herd al this she was not ameved
Neither in word or chere or in continance
For as hit semed she was not agreued
She seide lord al lyth in ȝour plesaunce
Mi child and I with hertly obeysaunce
Been ȝoures al and ȝe may saue ⁊and spille
Ȝoure oune thyng whether þᵗat ȝe wille
¶ Ther may no thyng god my soule saue
Lykynge to ȝou þat may displese me
Ne I desire no thyng to haue
Ne drede to lese saue only ye
This wil is myn herte ⁊and ay shal be
No lengthe of tyme or deeth may hit deface
Neither chānnge my corage in to oþer place
¶ Glad was the marquys for hire answerynge
But ȝit he feyned as he weere notso
Al drery was his cheere and his lokynge
Whan she schulde out of þe chambre goo
Sone after þis a forlong wey or two
He pleynly hath tolde al his entente
Vn to aman whiche to his wyf he sente
¶ A maner seriaunt was þis pryue man
Þe whiche þat feitful ofte I founde he hadde
In thynges grete and eke suche folk wel can
Doon execucions of thynges badde
The lord knew wel þat he hym loued ⁊and dradde
And whan þis sergeaunt wiste his lordes wille
In to þe chambre he stalked hym wel stille
¶ Ma dame he saide ȝe mote for ȝeue it me
Though I do thyng to whiche I am constreyned
Ye been so wys þat weel knowen ȝe
That lordes hestes moun not ben feyned
Þei mowen wel ben wailed or compleyned
But men mot nede vn to hire lust obeie
And so wol I þere is nomore to seie
¶ That child I am comaunded to take
And spak nomore but oute þe child he hente
Despitously and gan a chere make
As he wolde han slayn him or he wente
Grysilde mote al suffre and al consente
And as a lamb sche sitteþ meek ⁊and stille
¶ And leet þis cruel ʆsergeaunt haue his wille
Suspecte was þe fame of þis man
Suspecte his face suspecte his word also
Suspecte þe tyme þat he þis by gan
For hire doughter þat ȝhe loued so
Sche wende he wolde han slayn hit right þoo
But natheles she neither wepte ne syede
Confoormynge hire to þat þe markys lykede
¶ And atte laste speke ȝhe bygan
And mekely to þe seriaunt prayde
So as he was a worþi gental man
Þat she most kysse hire child er þat it deide
And in hire barme þis litel child she leide
With ful sad face and gan þe child to blisse
And lulled hit and after gan hit kysse
¶ And þus she seide in hyre benyngne voys
Fare wel my child I shal þe neủere see
But sithen I haue marked þe with þe croys
Of þilke fader I blessed mote þou be
That for vs deide vpon þe roode tre
Thi soule litel child I hym betake
For þis nyght shalt þou deien for my sake
¶ I trowe þat to a norice in þis cas
Hit had been hard þis reuþe forto see
Wel myghte a moder than crye alas
But natheles so sad stedefast was she
Þat sche endured al adủersite
And to þe serieaunt mekely she sayde
Haue here aȝen my lytel yonge mayde
And gpþ now quod she and doth my lordes heste
And oo þing wolde I pray of youre grace
Þat but my lord forbede ȝow atte leste
Buryeth þis litel body in som place
That no bestes ne bryddes hit torace
But he no word to þe purpos wolde seie
But took þe child and wente vpon his weye
¶ This sergeaunt come to þe lord agayn
And of Griseldes wordes ⁊and hire chere
He tolde hym poynt for point in short ⁊and playn
And hym psentyd with his doughter deere
Somwhat þis lord had rewthe in his manere
But natheles his purpos helde he stille
As lordes doone whan thei wole haue here wille
¶ And bad this sergeaunt ful pduely
He shulde wel softe þis child wynde and wrappe
With al cdcıı̄unstaunce tenderly
And carie it in a cofre or in a lappe
But vp peyne his head of for to swappe
Þat noman shulde knowe of his entent
Ne whennes he come ne whider he went
¶ But at Boloyne to his suster dere
That þo of Pauye was countesse
He shulde hire take and shewe hire þis matere
Bysechynge hire to doone hire besynesse
This child to fostre in al g;adnesse
And whos child þat hit was he bad hire hide
From eủery wight for ought þat myghte betyde
This sergeaunt goþ and haþ fulfillid this þing
But to þis marquys now retorne we
For now goþ he wel ofte ymagynynge
If by hys wyf he myghte see
And by hire wordes ꝑperceyue þat she
Were chaunged but he couthe neủere fynde
But eủere in oon I lyk sad and kynde
As glad as humble as besy in ʆseruyse
And eke in loue as she was wont to be
Was she to hym on euery maner wyse
Ne of hir doughter a word spak she
None accident for non adủersite
Was seen in hire ne neuere hire doughter name d
Nempned she for ernest ne for game
¶ In this estat passed been foure ȝeere
Er she with childe was but as god wolde
A knaue child she bare by þis walter
Wel gᵃcious and faire to byholde
And whenne folk hit to his fader tolde
Nought only he but alle þe cōnntre merye
Was for þe child and god þei þonke and herye
¶ Whan it was two ȝere oolde ⁊and from þe brest
Departed from his norice on aday
This marquys caught ȝet anoþ̉er lest
To tempten his wif ȝit ofter if he may
O nedeles was she tempted in assay
But wedded men knowen no mesure
Whan þei fynde a pacient creature
¶ Wyf quod this markys ȝe han herd or þis
My peeple sekesekesekexxbereth oure mariage
And namely sithen my sone born ys
Now it is wors þat euer in oure age
The murmoᵘur sleeth myn herte ⁊and my corage
For to myn eeres comeþ þe voys so smerte
Þat hit wel ney destroyeth al myn herte
¶ Now seie men þus whan walter is aagoon
Than shal þe blood of Ianycle succede
And been oure lord for other haue we noon
Suche wordes seyn my peple hit is no drede
Wel ought I of suche murmoᵘur taken hede
For certeynly I drede suche sentence
Though þey nought pleynly speke in myn audience
¶ I wolde lyue in pees yf þat I myghte
Wherfore I am disposed vtterly
As I his suster ʆserued by nyghte
Ryght so I thenke to serue hym pduely
Þus warne I ȝow þat ȝe not sodeynly
Out of ȝoure self for no wo shulde outraye
Beeth pacient and þerof I ȝou pray
¶ I haue quod she seid and euere shal
I wole desire no thyng certayn
But as ȝow lust not greueth me at al
Though þat my doughter and my sone be slayn
At ȝoure comaundement þis is to sayn
I haue had no part of children tweyne d
But first syknesse and after woo and peyne
¶ Ȝe beeth oure lord doth with ȝoure owne thyng
Ryght as ȝou lust and asketh no reed of me
For as I lefte at hom al my clothynge
Whan I ferst came to ȝou ryght so quod sche
Lefte I my wil and al my liberte
And took ȝoure clothynge wherfore I ȝou preye
Do ȝoure wil I wole to hit obey
¶ And certes If I had pscience
Ȝoure wil to knowe or ȝe ȝoure lust me tolde
I wolde it doone with oute necligence
But now I woot ȝoure lust and what ȝe wolde
Al ȝoure plesaunce ferme ⁊and stable I holde
For wiste I þat my deeth wolde do ȝou ese
Gladly wolde I suffre it ȝou to plese
¶ Deth may make non comparysoun
Vn to ȝoure loue and whan þis markys say
Þe constaunce of his wyf he caste his heed a dou
And his eyen two ⁊and wondred hou she may
In suche penaunce suffre al þis array
And forth he goth with drery contynaunce
But to his herte hit was wel gret penance
¶ This egre sergeaunt in þe same wyse
Þat he hire doughter caughte right so he
Or werse if he coude werse devyse
Hath caught hire childe þat was ful of beaute
And eủere in oon so pacient was she
That she no chere made of heuynesse
But kysseth hire sone and after gan him blesse
¶ Saue þis she preyde hym if þat he myghte
Hire litel sone he wolde on erthe gᵃue
Hise tendre lymes delicat to sighte
Fro foules and fro bestes to saue
But she noon answere of hym myghte haue
He wente his way as he no thyng roughte
But in to Boloyne tenderly it broughte
This markys wondereþ euer lenger þe more
Vpon hire pacience and if that he
Ne hadde soþely knowe þerbifore
That ꝑperfitly hire children loued she
He wolde haue wende þat of som sotilte
And of malice or cruel corage
That she had suffred þis wiþ sad visage
¶ But he knew þat next hym self certayn
Sche loued hire childryn best in euery wyse
But now of wommen wolde I aske fayn
Ȝif þese assaies myght nought suffise
What couthe a sturdy housbonde devyse
To pue hire wifhode and hire stedefastenesse
And be continuynge in sturdynesse
But þere ben folke of suche condicion
¶ That whan þei han a certeyn purpos take
Thei konne not stynte of here entencioun
But as þei were bounden to a stake
Thei wole not of þat purpos slake
Right so þis marquys fully hath purposed
To tempten his wyf as he was first disposed
¶ He wayteþ if by wordes or contynaunce
If she to hym was chaunged of corage
But neủere couthe he fynde varyaunce
She was eủere in herte ⁊and in visage
And euer þe ferþer þat she was in age
The more trewer if it were possible
She was to him in loue ⁊and more penyble
¶ For whiche it semeth þus þat of hem two
Ther was but oon wil for as walt̉er lust
The same lust was hire plesaunce also
And god be þonked al fel for þe beste
Sche shewede wel for non wordly vnrest
A wyf as of hire self nothyng sholde
Willen in effecte but as hire housbonde wolde
¶ The sclaunder of walter ofte wyde spradde
Þat of a cruel herte wyckedly
For he a poore wōmman wedded hadde
Hath murþred boþe his children pduely
Whiche murmour was among hem comōnnly
No wonder was for to þe peples ere
Ther come no worde but þat þei murþred were
¶ For suche as of his peple þerbyfore
Had loued him wel disclaundre of his name
Made hem þat þei hated him þ̉erfore
To been a mordrer is an hateful name
But natheles for ernest nefor game
He of his cruelte wolde not a stynte
To tempte his wyf was al his entente
¶ Whan þis doughter twelue ȝere was of age
He to þe Court of Rome in sotil wyse
Enformed of his wille sente his message
Comaundynge hem suche billes to devyse
As to his cruel purpos may suffise
How þat þe pope for his peples reste
Bade him wedde another wyf ȝif him leste
¶ I seie he bad þei sholde contrefete
The popes bulles makynge mencioun
Þat he hath leue his ferste wyf to lete
As by þe popes dispensacioıı̄un
To stynte rancour and dissenciou
By twyxe his peple and him þus spak þe bulle
The whiche þei han publisshed atte fulle
¶ The rude peple as no wonder is
Wende ful wel hit hadde be right soo
But þese tydynges come to Grisildis
I deme þat hire herte was ful woo
But she like sad for euermo
Disposid was þis humble creature
The aduersite of fortune al to endure
¶ A bydynge eủere his lust and his plesaunce
To whom she was ȝeuen herte ⁊and al
As to hire wordly suffisaunce
But certeynly for his storie telle I shal
This marquys I wryten hath in special
A lettre in whiche he sheweþ his entente
And sykerly to boloyne it sente
To þe Erle of Pavye whyche þat he had so
Wedded his suster he preyde specialy
To bryngen hym aȝen his children two
In honurable estat al openly
But oo thyng he him preyde vttrely
Þat he to no wyght thou men wolde enquere
Scholde nought telle whoos children þe weere
But seie þat þe mayden sholde wedded be
Vnto þe marquys of saluse anon
And as þe Erle was prayed so dede he
For at a day I sette he on his weie is goon
Toward saluse and lordes many oon
In ryche array þis mayde for to gyde
Hire ȝonge broþer rydyng by hire syde
¶ Arraied was to ward þis mariage
This mayde fresshe ful of gemmes cleere
Hire brother that seuen ȝer was of age
Arayed eke was fresshely on his maneere
And in grete noblesse and glad chiere
Toward saluces shapynge hire Iournay
Fro day to day þey ryden forth here way
¶ Among al þis after his wycked vsage
This marquys ȝit his wyf to tempte more
To þe vttrest preef of hire corage
Fully to haue exꝑperience and lore
Ȝif þat she were as stedefast as byfore
He on a day in open audience
Wel boystously haþ seide hire þis sentence
¶ Certes Grisilde I hadde I now plesaunce
To han ȝou to my wyf for ȝoure goodnesse
And for ȝoure treuþe and ȝoure obeysaunce
Nought for ȝoure lynage ne for ȝoure richesse
But hit is now knowen in verray sothnesse
That in gret lordschipe If I wol avise
Ther is gret soủeraignte in sondry wyse
¶ I may not don as eủery plowh man may
My peple me constrayneth for to take
Another wyf and cryen day by day
And eke þe pope rancour for to slake
Consenteth hit þat dar I vndertake
And trewly þus moche I wole ȝow say
My newe wyf is comynge by þe way
¶ Be stronge of herte and voyde anon hire place
And þilke dowere þat ȝe brought to me
Take hit aȝen I graunte hit of my grace
Retorneþ to ȝoure fadres hous quod he
No man may al way haue ꝓprosꝑperite
With euene herte I rede ȝou to endure
The strook of fortune or of auenture
¶ And she aȝen answerde in pacience
My lord quod she I woot and wiste alway d
How þat I swore ȝour magnificence
And my pouert no man can ne may
Maken noon comparisou hit is no nay
I heeld me neủere digne in no manere
To be ȝoure wyf ne ȝit ȝoure chambrere
¶ And in þis hous þere ȝe me lady made
The heyghe god take I for my wytnesse
So wysly as he my soule glade
I helde me lady ne maystresse
But humble seruant to ȝoure worthinesse
And euere shal while my lyf may endure
A bouen euery worthi creature
¶ That ȝe so longe of ȝoure benygnyte
Han holde me in honoure and in nobleie
Where as I was not worthi for to be
þat þonke I god and ȝou whom I preye
Forȝelde it ȝow þere is no more to seie
Vn to my fader gladly wol I wende
And with him dwelle þere to my lyues ende
¶ There as I was fostred a child ful smal
Til I be deed þere my lyf wil I lede
A widewe cleene in herte body and al
For sithen I ȝaf to ȝow my maydenhede
And am ȝoure trewe wyf hit is no drede
God shilde suche a lordes wyf to take
Another man to housbonde or to make
¶ And of ȝoure newe wyf god of his grace
So gᵃunte ȝow welþe and ꝓprosꝑperite
For I wole gladly ȝelde hire my place
In whiche I was blissful wont to be
For sithen hit lyketh ȝou my lord quod she
Þat whilom weren al myn hertes
That I schal goon I wyl goon whan ȝow leste
¶ But þere as ȝe ꝓprofre me suche dowaire
As I first broughte hit is wel in my mynde
Hit were my wrecched clothes no þing faire
The whiche to me now weere ful harde to fynde
O god how gentil and how kynde
Ye semed by ȝoure speche and ȝoure visage
Þe day þat maked was oure mariage
¶ But sothe is saide algate I fynde it trowe
For in effecte is pued now on me
Loue is not olde as whan hit is newe
For certes lord for noon adủersite
To deien in this cas hit shal not be
That in word or werke I shal repente
That I ȝou ȝaf myn herte in good entente
¶ My lord ȝe woot þat in my fadres place
Ȝe diden me stripen out of my pore wede
And richely ȝe cladden me of ȝoure grace
To ȝow brought I nought elles out of drede
But feith nakednesse and maydenheede
But here aȝen ȝoure cloþinge I restore
And eke my weddyng ryng for euere more
¶ The remenaıı̄unt of ȝoure Ieweles redy be
With ynne ȝoure chambre dar I saufly seyn
Naked out of my fadres hous quod she
I come ⁊and naked I mote Iturne agayn
Al ȝoure plesaunce wol I folowe fayn
But ȝit I hope hit be not ȝoure entente
Þat I smokles out of ȝoure Paleys wente
¶ Ȝe kouthe not do so dishonest a thyng
That ilke wombe in whiche ȝoure children lay
Scholde before þe peple in my walkynge
Be seyn al bare wherfore I ȝou pray
Lat me not lyke a worme goon by þe way
Remembre ȝow myn owne lord so deere
I was ȝoure wyf þough I vnworthi were
¶ Wherfore in gwerdoıı̄un of my maydenhede
Whiche þat I broughte and not aȝen bere
As voucheth sauf to ȝeue me to my nede
But suche a smok as I was wont to were
Þat I therwith may hele þe wombe of here
Þat was ȝoure wyf and here I take my leue
Of ȝou myn owne lord lest I ȝou greue
¶ The smok quod he þat þou hast on þi bak
Late hit be stille and bere hit forth with þe
But wel vnneþe þat word he spak
But wente his way for ruþe and pite
Byfore þe folk hire selue strepiþ she
And in hire smok with heed and foot al bare
Toward hire fader hous forþ is she fare d
¶ The folk folewed wepynge in here weie
And fortune eủere þei cursen as þe goon
But she fro wepynge kepte hire eyen dreye
Ne in this tyme word spak she noon
Hire fader þat þis word herd anoon
Cursed þe day and tyme þat nature
Shoop him to be alyue creature
¶ For oute of doute þis olde poủere man
Was eủere suspecte of hire mariage
For eủere he demed sithen it by gan
That whan þe lord I fillid had his corage
Hym wolde thynke hit was a disꝑparage
To his estat so lowe alyghte
And voyden hire as sone as eủere he myghte
¶ Aȝenst hise doughter hastyly goth he
For he be þe noyse of folk knew hire comynge
And with hire olde cote as it myghte be
He keủered hire wel sorwefully wepynge
But on hire body myghte he hit not brynge
For rude was þe cloth and more of age
Be dayes fele than hire mariage
¶ Thus with hire fader for a certeyn space
Dwelleth þis flour of wyfly pacience
Þat neuer by hire wordes ne by hire face
Byfore þe folk ne in hire absence
Ne shewed she þat to hire was doon offence
Ne of heye estat in remembraunce
Ne hadde she as by hire contynaunce
¶No wonder is for in gret estat
Hire goost was eủere in pleyne humylite
No tender mouth ne herte delicat
Ne pompe ne semblant of ryalte
But ful of pacience and benygnyte
Discreet and pruydeles and eủere honoᵘurable
And to hire housbonde eủere meek ⁊and stable
¶ Men speke of Iob and most of his humblesse
As clerkes whan hem lust can wel endite
Namly of men but in sothfastnesse
Thoxgh clerkes preyse wommen but alyte
Þer can no man in humblesse hem acquite
As wōmmen can ne be half so trewe
As wōmmen ben but hit be fallen newe
¶ From boloyne is þis Erle of Pavy come
Of whiche þe word sprong to more and to lesse
And to þe peples eres alle and some
Was kouthe eke a newe marquyssesse
He with him broughte in suche pompe ⁊and rychesse
That was neủere seie with mannes eye
So noble array in west lumbardye
¶ The marquys þa shoop and knewe al þis
Er þat þis Erle was come sente his message
For þilke sely pore Grisildis
And she with humble herte ⁊and glad visage
Nought with swollen þought in hire corage
Come at his heste and on hire knees hire sette
And reuerently and wisly she him grette
¶ Grisilde quod he my wil is vtterly
Þis mayden þat shal wedded ben vn to me
Resceyued be to morwe as really
As it is possible in myn hous to be
And eke þat eủery wyght in his degre
Haue his estate in sittinge and seruise
And also plesaunce as ȝe can best devise
¶ I haue no wōmman suffisaunt certayn
The chambres to arraye in ordynance
Thou knowest eke of olde al my plesaunce
Þough þyn array be badde and euel byseie
Do þou þi deuer at þe leste weye
¶ Nought only lord þat I am glad quod she
To do ȝoure lust but I desire also
Ȝow for to plese and serue in my degre
With outen feyntise ⁊and schal eủermo
Ne neủere for no wele ne for no woo
Ne schal þe goost with ynne myn herte stynte
To loue ȝou best with al my trewe entente
¶ And with þat word she gan þe hous to dighte
And tables to sette and beddes to make
And peyned hire to do al þat she myghte
Prayeng the chambreres for goddes sake
To hasten hem ⁊and faste swepe and shake
And she þe moste seruisable of alle
Hath euery chambre arrayd and his halle
¶ Aboute vnderne gan þis Erle o alyghte
That with hym broughte þese noble children tweie
For whiche þe peple ran to see þat syghte
And hire array so richely beseye
And þan atarst amonges hm þei gonne seie
That walter was no fool þogh him leste
To chaunge his wyf for hit was for þe beste
¶ For she is fairer as þei demen alle
Þan is Grisilde and more tendre of age
And fairer fruyt be twen hem shulde falle
And more plesaunce for hire hye lynage
Hire broþer so faire was of his age
That hym to seen the peple had caught plesaunce
Comendynge now þe marquys goủernaunce
¶ O sterne peple vnsad and vntrewe
Euere vndiscreet and chaungynge as a vane
Delytynge eủere in rumoᵘur þat is newe
For lyke þe mone euere wexe ȝe and wane
Euer ful of clappynge dere Inow a Iane
Ȝoure dome is fals ȝoure constaıı̄unce euel pueþ
A wel gret fool is he þat on ȝow leueþ
¶ This saiden sad folk in þat citee
Whan þat þe peple gased vp and doıı̄un
For þei were glad right for þe nouelte
To make a newe lady of hire tou
No more of þis make I menciou
But to Grisilde aȝen wol I me dresse
And tellen hire constance⁊and hire besynesse
¶ Wel besy was Grisilde on euery thyng
That to þe fest was ꝑpertynent
Right nought was she a basshed of hire clothyng
Þough þei were rude and eke som del to rent
But with glad chere to þe gate is went
With oþer folk to greten þe marquyssesse
And after doth she forth hire besynesse
¶ With wel glad chere þe gestes she reseyueth
And buxomlyche eủeriche in his degre
Þat noman diffaute þere ꝑperseyueth
But exxre þei wondereþ what she myȝte be
That in so poure aray was forto see
And couthe suche honour and reuerence
And worthyly þ pysen hire prudence
¶ In al þis mene whil she ne stynte
This mayden and eke hire broþer to comende
With al hire herte and benygne entente
So wel þat noman coude hire pirys amende
But at þe las whan þese lordes wende
Te sitten adou he gan to calle
Grysilde as she was bisy þe halle
¶ Grisilde quod he as it were in his play
How likeþ þe my wyf here beaute
Right wel quod sche my lord for in good fay
A fairer sawh I neủere none þan sche
I pray to god so ȝeue ȝou ꝓprosꝑperete
And so hope I þat he wil to ȝou sende
Plesaunce I nowh yn to ȝoure lyues ende
¶ But oo thyng I beseche ȝou ⁊and warne also
That ye pryke with no turmentynge
Þis tender mayden as ȝe han doon mo
For sche is fostred in hir norisshynge
Wel tenderly eyenge
Sche coude not adủersite endure
As couthe a pore fostred creature
¶ And whan þis walter sawh hire pacience
Hire glad chere and no malice at al
And he so ofte may doon hire offence
And she euer constant and sad as a wal
Continuynge euere hire Innocence ouer al
This sturdy marquys gan his herte dresse
To rewe vpon hire wyfly stedfastnesse
¶ This is I now Grisilde myn quod he
Be namore agast and euel apaied
I haue thi feith and þi benygnyte
As wel as eủer woman was assaied
In grete estate and porely arayed
Now knowe I dere wyf þi stedfastnesse
And hire in armes took and gan to kysse
¶ And she for wonder toke þerof no keepe
She herde not what þyng þat he seide
She ferde as she hadde sterte out of hire slepe
Til she out of þe masednesse abreyde
Grisilde quod he by god þat so vs deyde
Thou art my wyf non oþer I haue
Ne neủere hadde as god my soule saue
¶ This is thi doughter whiche þou hast supposed
To ben my wyf and none other feithfully
Schal be myn eyrr as I haue euere disposed
Þou bare hire in þi body trewely
At boloyne haue I kepte hem preuly
Take hem aȝen for þou maist nat seye
Þat þou hast lorne eny of thy children tweie
¶ And foolk þat oþer wyse han seide of me
I warne hem þat I haue don þis dede
For no malice ne for no cruelte
But forto assaye þyn womanhede
And nought for to slee my children god forbede
But for to kepen hem pduely and stille
Til I thi purpos knewe and al þi wille
¶ And whan she þis herde aswowne dou she falleth
For pitous ioye and after hire swownynge
She boþe hire yonge children to hire calleþ
And in hire armes pitously wepynge
Enbrased bothe tenderly kessynge
Wel lyk amoder wit hire salte teres
She baþed bothe hire visage and hire heres
¶ Oo whiche a pitous thyng hit was to see
Hire swownynge and hire pitous voys to here
Gᵃmercy my lord so god I thanke ȝou quod she
That ȝe han saued me my children dere
Now rekke I neuere to be ded right heere
Sythen I stonde in ȝoure loue and in ȝoure gᵃce
No fors of deeth ne whan my spirit pace
¶ O tendre o dere o ȝonge children myne
Ȝoure woful moder wende stedfastly
That cruel houndes or som vermyn
Had eten ȝou but god of his mercy
And ȝoure benygne fader tenderly
Hath don ȝou kepte and þat same stoıı̄unde
Al sodeynly she swapte to þe grounde
¶ And in hire swowne so sadly holdeth she
Hire children two whan she gan hem brace
That with grete sleight and difficulte
The children from hire armes þei gan vase
O many atere apitous face
Doıı̄un ran of hem þat stoden hire besyde
Vnnethe aboute hire myghte þei abyde
¶ Walter hire vp seth and hire sorwe gladeþ
She aryset vp al abachsed from hire traunce
And euery wyght hire ioye and feste makeþ
Til she haue caught aȝen hire contynance
Walter hire doth so feithfully plesaunce
Þat it was deynte to see þe chere
Bytwyxe hem tw þei ben mette in fere
¶ Þese ladyes whan thei here tyme sai
Han taken hire and in to chambre gon
And stripen hire out of hire rude aray
And in a cloth of gold þat bryght shon
With a crowne of many a riche stoon
Vpon hire heed þei hire in to halle broughte
And þere she was honured as sche oughte
¶ Thus hath þis pitous day a blisful ende
For euery man and wōmman doth his myght
This day in merthe and reuel to dispende
Til on þe welkene schone þe sterres bryght
For more solempne in eủery mannys syght
This feste was and gretter of costage
Þan was þe reuel at þe mariage
¶ Wel many aȝere in heygh ꝓprosꝑperite
Lyuen þese two in concorde and in reste
And rychely his doughter maryed he
Vn to alord oon of þe worthieste
Of al Italie and than in pees and reste
Hys wyfes fader yn his court he keepeþ
Til þat his soule out of his body crepeþ
¶ Hys sone entreþ in his herytage
In reste and pees after his fader day
And fortunat was eke in maryage
Al put he not his wyf in assay
This world is not strong hit is no nay
As it haþ ben in olde tymes ȝore
And herkeneth what þe Auctour seith þ̉erfore
¶ This storye is sde not þat wyfes sholde
Folowen Grisilde as in humylite
For it were importable þough þe wolde d
But þat euery wyght in his degre
Scholde be constant in adủersite
This storye whiche he with heygh style endyteth
With pacience Grisilde he quyteþ
¶ For sithen a womman was so pacient
Vn to a mortel man wel more we oughte
Receyuen al in gree þat god vs sent
For grete sceles he preueth þat he boughte
But he tempteþ no men þat he boughte
As seith seynt Iame ȝif ȝe his pistel reede
He pueth folk al day it is no drede
¶ And suffreþ vs as for oure exercise
Wiþ scharpe schowres of aduersite
Wel ofte to ben beten in sondry wyse
Nought for to knowen vs for certes he
Or we weere born knewe al oure freelte
And for oure beste is al our goủernaunce
Late vs it haue þanne in v̉ertuous suffraunce
But oo witt herkeneþ lordynges or ȝe goo
It weere ful hard nowe a dayes
In al a toun fynde Grisildis þre or two
For if þei weere put in suche assaies
Þe gold of hem hath nowe so harde alayes
With bras þat þough þe kynde be faire at yȝe
Hit wole rather breste a two þan plye
GRysilde is ded and eke hire pacience
And boþe attones buried in Itayle
For whiche I crie in open audience
No wedded man be hardy to assayle
His wyfes pacience in truste to fynde
Grysildes for in certayn he shal fayle
O noble wyfes ful of hyhe prudence
Late none humilite youre tonge nayle
Ne late no clerk haue cause or diligence
To wryte of ȝow a storie of suche muayle
As of Grysildes pacient and kynde
Lest chichyuache yow swelowe in hire entraile
Foloweþ ekke þat holdeþ no silence
But euere answereþ at þe countretaile
Beth no by daffed for ȝoure Innocence
But scharply take on ȝou þe goủernayle
Emprenteth wel þis lessōnn in ȝoure mynde
For comune ꝓprofit sith it may availe
Ne drede hem nought doth hem no reuerence
For þough þyn housbonde armed be in mayle
The arewes of þi Crabbed eloquence
Schal ꝑperse his brest and eke his Auentaile
In Ielousye I rede eke þou him bynde
And þat þou make hym couche as doth a quayle
If þou be faire þere folk ben in psence
Shewe þou þi visage and þine apparaile
If þou be foul be fre of þi dispence
To gete þe frendes ay do thy trauayle
Be ay of chiere as lyght as lef on lynde
And late him care ⁊and wepe ⁊and wrynge ⁊and waile
Ȝe arche wyfes standeth at ȝoure defence
Sithe ȝe ben stronge as is a grete Camayle
Ne suffreth not þat man don ȝou offence
And sclendre wyfes fieble as in bataile
Beth egre as a Tygre ȝonde in ynde
Ay clappeth as a Mylle I ȝou coıı̄unsaile
Here endith the Clerke of Oxenford
And here begynneth the ꝓprolog of the Frankeleyn .
THis worthi clerk whan endid was his tale
Oure seide and swor by goddes bones
Me weere leuere þan a barel ale
My wyf at home hadde herd þis legend ones
This is a gentil tale for the nones
As to my purpos wiste my wylle
But þing þat wil not be lat it be stille
I haue a wyf þou she pore be
Ȝit she hath an hepe of vyces lo
For of hire tonge a moche shrewe is she
And to my wylle þe contrarye wil she do
Therof no force lete alle suche þinges go
But wyte ȝe what in consail be it saide
Me rewyth sore þat at I am to hire taide
Sire frankeleyn comeþ nere ȝif hit ȝoure wil be
And telle vs atale as ȝe are a worthi man
Hit schal be do truly oost quod he
I wil ȝow telle as hertely as I can
Holdeþ me excused þough I vnworthi am
To telle ȝou a tale for I wole not rebelle
Aȝens ȝoure wille atale wole I telle
Here endith the ꝓprolog .. And begynneth the tale

(base) I sleep neuere in the Mount of parnaso

(base) Or ellis swiche as men dye or peynte

(base) Hath swich a pitee caught of his penance

div.l: (base) That neuere in al his lyf he day ne nyght
(base) Ne sholde vpon hym take no maistrye
(base) Agayn hir wyl ne kithe hire Ialousye
(base) But hire obeye and folwe hir wyl in al
(base) As any louere to his lady shal
(base) Saue that the name of soueraynetee
(base) That wolde he haue for shame of his degree
(base) She thonked hym and with ful gret humblesse
(base) She seyde sire sith of youre gentilesse
(base) Ye profre me to haue so large a reyne
(base) Ne wolde neuere god bitwix vs tweyne
(base) As in my gilt were outher werre or stryf
(base) Sire I wol be youre humble trewe wyf
(base) Haue heer my trouthe til that myn herte breste
(base) Thus been they bothe in quiete and in reste
(base) For o thyng sires saufly dar I seye
(base) That freendes euerich oother moote obeye
(base) If they wol longe holden compaignye
(base) Loue wol nat be constreyned by maistrye
(base) Whan maistrie comth the god of loue anon
(base) Beteth his wynges and farwel he is gon
(base) Loue is a thyng as any spirit free
(base) Wommen of kynde desiren libertee
(base) And nat to been constreyned as a thral
(base) And so doon men if I sooth seyn shal
(base) Looke who that moost is pacient in loue
(base) He is at his auantage al aboue
(base) Pacience is an heigh vertu certeyn
(base) For it venquysseth as thise clerkes seyn
(base) Thynges that rigour sholde neuere atteyne
(base) For euery word men may nat chide or pleyne
(base) Lerneth to suffre or ellis so moot I gon
(base) Ye shul it lerne wher so ye wole or non
(base) For in this world certeyn ther no wight is
(base) That he ne dooth or seith som tyme amys
(base) Ire siknesse or constellacioun
(base) Wyn wo or chaungyng of complexioun
(base) Causeth ful ofte to doon amys or speken

And sires also hit helith Ielousye
And þough aman be fallen in a Ielouse rage
Lete maken with þis water his potage
And neủere shal he his wif mys truste
Though he þe sothe of hir defaute wiste
Al had she taken preestes tweyne or thre
Here is a myteyn eke þat ȝe may see
He þat his hond wil putte in þis myteyne
He schal haue multiplying of his greyne
When he hath sowen be it whete or Otes
So þat he bring me good pans or elles grotes
And men and wōmmen oo þing I warne ȝow
Ȝif any wight be in þis chirche now
That hath done synne horrible þat he
Dar not for shame of it shryuen be
Or any wōmman be sche ȝong or olde
That hath made hire housbond Cokewolde
Suche folk schul haue no power no no grace
To offre to my relikes in this place
And who so fyndeth hym out of suche blame
Thei wol come vp and offre in goddes name
And I assoyle hem by þe autorite
Suche as my bulle was graunted to me
By this gawde haue I wonen eủery ȝere
An hundred marke sythyns I was ꝑpardoner I stond I lyke a clerk

div.l: I stond I lyke a Clerk in my pulpitte
And schew lewed peples synne I sette
I preche so as I haue lered byfore
And telle an hundred Iapes more
Then peyne I me to streche forth þe necke
And Est and west vpon þe peple I bekke
As doth a dowue sittyng on a berne
My hondes and my tong gon ful ȝerne
That it is ioye to se my bysynes
Of auariche and suche cursednes
Is al my pching for to make hem fre
To ȝeue her pans and namly vnto me
For myn entent is noght but forto wynne
And no þing for correction of synne
I rekk neuer whan þat þei ben buried
Þough þat here soules goon a blakburied
For certes many a pdicacion
Cometh ofte tyme of euyl entencion
Some for plesaunce of folk and for flaterie
To ben a vaunced by ypocrysie
And some for veynglorie and some for hate
For whan I dar not by oþ̉er wayes debate
Than wil I styng hem with my tong smert
In preching so þat he sal not stert
To ben diffamed falsely so þat he
Hath trespaced to my brethren or to me
For þough I telle not his ꝓpropre name
Men shal wel knowe þat it is þe same
By some signe and oþer ccustaıı̄unces
Thus smyte I folke þat doth vs displesaıı̄unces
Thus spitte I oute my venym vnder hew
Of holynesses to semyn holy and trew
But shortly myn entent I wil deuyse
I preche of no þing but of couetyse
Therfore my teme is ȝit and eủer was
Radix omnium malorum est cupiditas
Thus can I preche aȝens þe same vyce
Whiche þat I vse and þat is auarice
But þough my self be giltif in þat synne
Ȝit con I make oþer folke to wynne
From auarice and sore hem repente
But þat nys not my pⁱrincipal entent
I preche not but for couetise
Of þis matere it aught I now suffice
Then telle I hem ensamples mony on
Of old stories long tyme agon
For lewed peple louen tales old
Whiche þinges con þei report ⁊and hold
What trow ȝe that whils I may preche
And wynne gold and siluer for to teche
Þat I wil lyue in pouert wilfully
Nay nay I thought it neuere trewely
For I wil preche ⁊and begge in sondry londes
I wil not do no labour with my hondes
Ne make basketis and lyue þ̉erby
By cause I wil not lyuen ydelly
I wil none of þe aposteles cont̉refete
I wil haue money malt chese and whete
Al were it ȝeuen of þe porest page
Other of þe porest widew in a village
Al shulde hire children sterue for famyne
And I wil drinke þe lycorest of þe wyne
And haue a Ioly wenche in euery toune
But herkeneþ lordes in conclusion
Ȝoure lykyng is þat I shal telle a tale
Now I haue dronken a draught of corny ale
By god I hope I shal telle ȝou a thing
That shal by reson be at ȝoure lykyng
For þough my self be a ful vicious man
A moral tale ȝit I ȝou telle can
Whiche Iames wente to preche for to wynne
Now holdeth ȝoure pees my tale I wil bygynne
Here bygyneth . the tale .
iN flaundres whilome was a companye
Of ȝong folk þat haunted folye
As hasard Ryote stewes and tauernes
Harpes rubibes lutes and giternes
They dauncen and playn at þe dys nyght ⁊and day
And ete also oủer þat here myght may
Thorgh whiche þei do þe deuel sacⁱfise
With Inne þe deueles temple in sondry wyse
By suꝑperfluyte ab hominable
Here othes ben so grete ⁊and dampnable
That it is grisly for to here hem swere
Oure blissed lordes body þei to tere
Hem þought Iewes rent him noght I nowe
And ilke of hem at oþer synne lowhe
And right anone come In þen tomblisters
Fetys and smal and ȝong fruteres
Syngerys with harpes baudes ⁊and wafrers
Suche ben verray þe deuelys officers
To kyndle and blow þe fyre of lechery
Þat is annexed to glotonye
The holy wrytte take I to witnesse
Þat lecherie is in wyn and dronkenesse
Loo how þat dronken lothe vn kyndely
Lay by his doghteres two vnwittyngly
So dronken he was he nyst what he wroght
Herodes who so hath þe stories sought
When he of wyn was replete at his feste
Right at his owne table ȝaf his heste
To sleen þe baptist Iohn ful gilteles
Senek saith a good worde douteles
He saith he can no difference fynde
By twix aman þat is oute of his mynde
And aman þat is dronkelewe
But þat wodnesse is fallen in a schrewe
ꝐPerseuerith lenger þan doth dronkenesse
O glotonye ful of cursednesse
O cause first of oure confusioıı̄un
Oryginal of oure dampnacion
Til crist had bought vs with his blood agayn
Lo how dere shortly forto sayn
A bought was þe cursed vylanye
Corrupt was al þis world þorgh glotonye
Adam oure fader and his wif also
Fro paradys to labour and to wo
Were dryuen for þat wyse it is no drede
For whiles þat Adam fasted as I rede
He was in paradys and when þat he
Ete of þe fruyt defended on þe tre
Anoon he was oute cast to wo and peyne
O glotonye on þe wel ought vs pleyne
O wist a man how many maladyes
Folowith of excesse and of glotonyes
He wold ben þe more mesurable
Of his diete sittyng at his table
Alas þe short þrote þe tendre mouthe
Maketh þat Est ⁊and west North ⁊and southe
In erthe in eyer in water men to synke
To geten a gloton deynte mete ⁊and drynke
Of þis matere O poule wel can þou trete
Mete vn to wombe ⁊and wombe eke vnto mete
Schal god distroie both as poul seith
Alas a foule þing it is by my feyth
To say þis word and fouler is þe dede
When men so drynkith of þe white ⁊and rede
That of his þrote he maketh his pⁱriyuyee
Thurgh þilk cursid suꝑperfluite
The Apostel wepyng with pitous voys
Ther ben enemys of cristes croys
Of whiche þe ende is deth womb is her god
O womb o baly o stynkyng cod
Fulfilled of dong and of corrupcion
Atte either ende of þe foule is þe seson
How grete cost and labour is to fynde
Thise cokes . how þei stamp streyne ⁊and grynde
And turnene substaunce in to accident
To fulfille alle þi laborous talent
Out of þe hard bones knokk þei
The marie for þei cast not a way
That may go þorgh þe golet sof ⁊and swote
Of spicerye of leues bark and rote
Shal ben his sawce I made be delite
To makyn him ȝit a new appetite
But certes he þat haıı̄unteþ suche delices
Is deed whiles þat he lyuyth in tho vices
A lecherie þing is wyn and dronkenesse
It is ful of stryuyng and of wrecchidnes
O dronken man disfygured in thi face
Foul is þi breth foul art þou to enbrace
And þorgh þyn dronken nose sowneth þe sōnne
As þogh þou seidest ay sampson Sampsoıı̄un
And ȝit god woot Sampson dronk neủer no wyne
Thou fallest as it were a dronken swyne
Thin tonge is lost and alle þyn honest cure
For dronkennes is verray sepulture
Of mannys wytte and his discrecion
In whom þat drynke hath domynacion
He can noo conseil kepe it is no drede
Now kepe ȝou fro þe white and fro þe reede
Namely fro þe white wyn of lepe
Þat is to selle in fische strete ⁊and in chepe
This wyn of spayn crepith subtilly
In other wynes growyng fast by
Of whiche risith suche fumosyte
That whan aman hath dronken a draught or thre
And wenyth þat he be at home in chepe
Than is he in spayne right at þe toıı̄un of lepe
Nought at þe Rochel ne at burdeux tou
And þanne wole þei say sampson sampsoıı̄un
But herkenyth lordingꝭes oo word I ȝou pray
That alle þe soủerayne actes dar I say
Of victories in olde testament
That þorgh verray god þat is oipotent
Weren doone in abstinence and in praiere
Loketh þe bible and þer ȝe may it lere
Lokith attila þe grete conquerour
Deid in his slepe with shame ⁊and dishonour
Bledyng at his nose in dronkennesse
A Capitayne shuld lyue in soburnesse
And oủer alle þise a vise ȝou right wel
What was comanded vnto lamuel
Not samuel but lamuel say I
Redith þe bible and fyndith it expssely
Of wyn ȝeuyng of hem þat aren Iustice
No more of þis for it may suffice
And now þat I haue spokyn of glotony
Now wol I defend ȝou hasardy
Hasard is verray moder of lesynges
And of disceyt cursid for swerynges
Blaspheme of crist man slaughter ⁊and wast Also
Of bataile and of tyme and of forther mo
Hit is repreef and contrarie to honoure
For to be holden a comyn hasardoure
And eủer þe hyer he is of estate
The more he is holden desolate
Ȝif þat a pⁱrince vse hasardye
In alle goủernaunce and policie
He is as by comon opynion
Hold þe lasse in reputacion
Stilbon þat was hold a wyse embassatoure
Was send in to corinth with ful gret honoure
Fro Calydoyne to make hem alliance
And when he cam happed þis chānce
Þat alle þe grettest þat were of þat lond
Pleyng at þe hasard he hem fande
For whiche as sone as þat myght be
He stale him hom aȝen to his contre
And said þ̉er I wold not lese my name
I wold not take on me so gret diffame
For to allye ȝou to none hasardoures
Sendeth othir wyser Embassatoures
For by my trouthe me were leuer dye
Then I sculd ȝow to hasardoures allye
For ȝe þat ben so glorious in honoures
Schal not allye ȝou with hasardoures
As my wil ne as by my trete
Thise wyse philospher saide
Loke eke þat to þe kyng demetreus
The kyng of partes as þe book seith thus
Sent him a peire of dees of gold in skorne
For he had vsid hasardye þer by forne
For whiche he held his glorye and his renou
For no value of reputacion
Lordys myght fynde oþ̉er man playe
Honest I now to dryue þe day away
Now wole I speke of othes fals ⁊and grete
A word or two as oþ̉er bokes entrete
Grete swering is a þing abhominable
And false swering is moche more reprouable
The highe god for bar swering at alle
Witnesse of Matheu but in special
Of sweryng the holy Ieromye
Thou shalt swere soþ þyn othis ⁊and not lye
And swere in doome and eke in righwisnes
But Idel sweryng is a cursednes
By hold and see þat in the first table
Of high goddes hestes honourable
How þat two hestes of him is þis
Take noght my tale in Idelnes amys
Loo rather he ferbedith suche sweryng
Then homicide or any oþer þing
I say as þus by ordre it stondithe
This knowith þat his hestes vnderstondeth
How þat þe second heste of god is þat
And forther oủer I wil þe telle alle plat
Þat vengeance schal not parte fro his hous
Þat of his othes is so outragious
By goddes pcious hert and his nayles
And by hys blood þat is in hayles
Seuen is my chance and his fyue ⁊and þre
By goddes armes ȝif þou falsely play me
This dagger schal þorgh þyn hert goo
This fruyt cometh of þilke bones two
For swering Ire falsenes homicide
Now for þe loue of crist þat for vs deide
Leuyth ȝoure othes boþe grete and smale
For I schal telle ȝou a mueillous tale
Thise riotours of whiche I telle
Long erst or pⁱrime rong any belle
Were sette in a tauerne to drinke
And as þei satte þei said þei herd a belle clynke
By forn a corps was caried to his graue
Þat on of hem gan calle to his knaue
Go bet quod he and aske redyly
What corps is þat þat passith forth by
And loke þat þou reporte his name wel
Sire quod þis knaue it nedith neủer a del
Hit was me told er ȝe come here two houres
He was parde an old felaw of ȝoures
Al sodeynly was he slayn to nyȝt
For dronken as he sat vpon his benche vp ryȝt
Ther come a preuy theef men clepen deth
That in his contraye al þe peple sleth
And with his spere he smote his hert a two
And wente his way with oute wordes mo
He hath a þousand slayn þis pestilence
And maister er ȝe come in his presence
Me þinketh þat it were necessarie
For to be war of suche adủersarie
Beth redy for to mete him eủermore
Thus taught me my dame I say nomore
By seynt marye said þis tauernere
The child saith soth for he hath slayn to ȝere
Hennes oủer amyle with In a grete village
Boþe man and wōmman child and page
I trow his hīntacion be þer
To ben avysed grete wisdome it were
Or þat he did aman dishonoure
Ȝe goddis armes quod þis riotoure
Is it suche ꝑperil with him for to mete
I shal him sechyn by stye and by strete
I make a vow by goddis digne bones
Herkenyth felawis we þre ben alle ones
Lete vche of vs hold vp his hond to other
And eche of vs by come other brother
And we wil sle þis fals traytour deth
He shal be slayn he þat so mony sleth
By goddis dignite er it be nyght
To gidre han þise þre her hertes plight
To lyue and to dye ilke of hem with oþer
As þogh he were his owne borne broþer
And vp þei sterten and dronken in þis rage
And forth þei gon toward þat village
Of whiche þe taủerner hath spokyn byforn
And mony a grisly othe þen han þei sworn
And cristes blessid body þei to rente
That deth shal be ded ȝif þat we may him hente
When þei han goon not fully amyle
Right as þei wold haue troden ouer a stile
An old and a pore man with hem mette
This old man ful mekely hem grette
And said þus now lordys god ȝou se
The proudest of þise riotours þre
Answerid a ȝen what cherle with hard grace
Whi art þou alle for wrapped saue þi face
Whi lyuest þou so long in so grete age
This old man gan loke in his visage
And saide þus for I con not fynde
A man þough I wolde in to Inde
Neither in cite ne in non vilage
That wil changen his ȝouth for myn age
And therfore mote I haue myn age stille
As long tyme as it is goddes wille
Ne deth alas nyl nat haue my lyf
Thus walke I lyke a resteles caytif
And on þe grounde whiche is my moder gate
I knok with my staf Erly and late
And say leue moder late me Inne
Low how I vanshe flesshe blood ⁊and skynne
Alas whan shul my bones ben at reste
Moder with ȝou wold I change my cheste
Þat in my chambre long tyme hath be
Ȝe for an hier cloute to wrappe me
But ȝit to me she wol not do þat grace
For whiche ful welkid is my face
But sires to ȝou it is no curtesye
To spekyn vn til an old man vylaynye
But he trespas in word or elles in dede
In holy wryt ȝe may ȝoure self wel rede
A ȝenst an old man hoor vp on his heed
Ȝe shulde aryse therfore I ȝeue ȝou red
Ne doth vnto an old man harme as nowe
No more þan ȝe wold aman dide ȝowe
In age ȝif þat ȝe so long abyde
And god be with ȝou whether ȝe go or ride
I mote go þider as I haue to go
Nay old cherle by god þou shalt not soo
Sayde thise oþer hasardoures anōnne
Thou partest not so lyghtly by seynt Iohan
Thou spake right now of þilke traytoure deth
Þat in þis contray alle oure frendes sleeth
Haue here my trouth as þou art his aspye
Telle where he is or elles þou shalt die
By god and by þe holy sacrament
For sothely þou art of his assent
To sleen vs ȝong folk þou false thef
Now sires ȝif it be to ȝou so leef
To fynde deth turne vp þis crowkid way
For in þat groue I lefte hym by my fay
Vndir a tre and þere he wole abyde
Ne for ȝoure bost he nyl him no þing hide
Se ȝe þat oke right þer ȝe schul him fynde
God saue ȝou þat boght a ȝayn man kynde
And ȝow amend þus said þis old man
And euery of thise riotours ran
Til þei come to þe tre and þer þei fonde
Floreyns of gold fyne y coyned rounde
Wel nyghe a seuyn buschels as hem þought
No lenger þan after deth þai soght
But eche of hem so glad was of þat sight
For þat the florayns so faire be and bright
That down þei sette hem by þe pcious hord
The worst of hem he spak þe first word
Brethren qd he take hede what I say
My witte is grete þough I bourd ⁊and play
This tresour hath fortune to vs ȝeuen
In myrthe and Iolyte oure lyf to lyuen
And lyghtly so as it comyth so wil we spend
Eye pcious goddes hert who wende
To day þat we schuld haue so faire a grace
But myght þis gold be caried fro þis place
Home vnto my hous or elles to ȝoures
For wel y wote þat alle þis gold is oures
Then were we in high felicite
But trewely by day it may not be
Men wolde sayn þat we weren theefes stronge
And for owre owne tresour done vs honge
As wysely and as sleighly as it myght
This tresour most I caryed be by nyght
Wherfore I rede let loke among vs alle
To draw and lete see where þe cut wol falle
He þat hath þe cut with herte blithe
Schal renne to towne ⁊and þat ful swythe
To bring vs bred and drynk ful pⁱriuyly
And two of vs schul kepen ful subtilly
This tresour wel and ȝif he wil not tarye
Whenne it is nyght we wil þis tresour carye
By oon assent wher as vs lyketh best
That on of hem brought gras in his fiste
And bade hem drawe and loke on whom it wol falle
And it fel on þe ȝongest of hem alle
And forth toward þe toune he went anone
And also sone as he was gone
Þat on of hem spak vnto þat oþer
Thou wost wel þou art myn owne sworn broþer
Thyn profite wol I telle the a none
Thou wost wel þat oure felawe is gone
And here is gold and þat right grete plente
That it shal departid be among vs þre
But natheles if I can shape it so
Þat it deꝑparted were among vs two
Had I not done a frendes torne to þe
That oþer answerid I not how þᵗat myght be
I wold welle þat þe gold were oures two
What shul we do þat it myght be so
Schal it be conseil sayde þe first shrew
And I schal tellen in wordes fewe
What we schul don and brynge it aboute
I graunt quo þe oþer oute of doute
That by trouth I wil þe not be wreien
Now qd þe first þou wost wel we ben tweyn
And two of vs shul strenger be þan on
Loke when he is sette and þat anone
Aryse as þoughe þou woldest with hym play
And I shal ryuen him þorgh þe sydes tway
Whiles þat þou strogelest with him as in game
And with þi dagger loke þou do þe same
And þan schal al þis gold departed be
My dere frend by twyx the and me
Than may we boþe oure lustes fulfille
And pley at þe dyce ryght at oure owne wille
And thus a corded ben thise shrewes tweye
To sle þe þrid as ȝe herd me saye
This ȝongest whiche þat went to þe toun
Ful ofte in his hert it rolled vp and doun
The beaute of thise floreyns faire ⁊and bright
O lord qd he ȝif it so were I myght
Haue alle þis tresour to my self allone
Ther is no man þat lyuyth vndir trone
Of gold þat schuld lyue as mery as I
And at þe laste þe feend oure enmye
Put in his þought þat he shuld poysone bey
With whiche he myght sleen his felawes tweie
For whi þe fend fond him in suche lyuyng
Þat he had leue him to sorow bryng
For þis was outerly his entent
To sleen hem bothe and neủer to repent
And forth he goth no lenger wolde he tarye
In to þe toune vnto apoticarie
And preyde him þat he him wolde selle
Some poyson þat he myght his rattes kille
And eke þer was a polkat in his haw
That as he saide his Chapons had I slaw
And seyde he wolde wreke him ȝif he myght
Of vermyn þat distroied him by nyght
The potecarye answerd þow shalt haue
A þing þat als god my soule saue
In al þis world þer nys no creature
That ete or drynke of þis confecture
Noght but þe moıı̄untance of a corn of whete
Þat he ne schal his lyf anon for lete
Ȝe sterue he schal and þat in lasse while
Þan þou wolt gon apas not but a myle
This poyson þat is so hard and violent
This cursid man hath in his hond hit hent
This poyson in a box and sythene he ran
In to þe next strete vnto aman
And borwid him large botelles þre
To his felawes aȝen repairethe he
The thrid he kept clene for his drynke
For alle þe nyght he schope him to swynke
In carying of þat gold out of þat place
And when þis Riatour with sory grace
Had fillid with him his grete botelles þre
To his felawes aȝeyn repayreth he
What nedith it to sermon therof more
For right as þei hadde cast here deth byfore
Right so þei han him slayn and þat a nōnne

For by my trowthe I haue on myn aray
And nought on waste by stowed eủerydel
And for I haue be stowed hit so wel
To ȝoure honoure for goddes sake I saye
As be nought wroth but lete vs laughe ⁊and playe
Ȝe schuln my Ioly body haue to wedde
By god I nyl nought paye ȝou but a bedde
For ȝef hit me myn owne spouse dere
Turne hiderward and make bett̉er chere
This marchant say þer was no remedye
And for to chide hit nere but folye
Sethins þat the thing may nought amended be
Now wyf he sayde and I for ȝeue hit the
But by thyn lyf ne be no more so large
Kepe bet my good this ȝif I þe in charge
Thus endeth now my tale and god vs sende
Toillynge I nowȝ vnto oure lyfes ende
Here begynneth the ꝓprolog of the prioresse
WEl sayde by corpus dıı̄uns qd our Oste
Now lange mote þou sayle by þe see coste
Sire gentil mayster gentile marynere
God ȝeff þe monk a thousande laste quade ȝere
A ha felawes beeth war of suche a Iape
The monk put in þe mannes hood an ape
And in his wyfes eke by seint Austyn
Drawith no monkes more in to ȝoure In
But now passe oủer and lete vs seke aboute
Who shal now telle ferst of alle þis Route
Another tale and with þat word he saide
As curteisly as hit had ben amayde
My lady pryeres by ȝoure leue
So that I wyste I shulde ȝou nought greue
I wolde deme þat ȝe telle shulde
A tale next if so were that ȝe wolde
Now wole ȝe fouche sauf my lady dere
Gladly quod she and saide in þis manere
Here endith the prolog /
And begynneth the Tale
O lord oure lord thin name how merueylous
Is in this large worlde I spred qd she
For nought only thyn hand pcious
ꝐPerfourmed is by men of dignyte
But by þe mouthe of childrin þin bounte
ꝐPerformed is for on oure brest soukynge

l.hi: Some tyme shewen they þyn heryenge

div.l: Wherefore in laud as I can best or may
Of þe and of þe white lyly floure
Whiche þat þe bare and is a mayde alwey
To telle a storye I wil done my laboure
Nought þat I may encrece her honoure
For she her self is honoure and þ̉erto rote

l.hi: Of bounte next her sone of soules bote

div.l: O moder mayde O Mayde moder fre
O busch vnbrent brennyng in moyses syght
That Rauyscheþ doun fro þe deyte
Thurgh thin humbles þe goste þat in the alyght
Of whos vertu when he in þin herte alyght
Conceyued was þe Fadres Sapience

l.hi: Helpe me to telle hit in þin reuerence

div.l: Lady thin bounte and thin magnificence
Thin vertu and thin grete humylite
Ther may no tonge expsse in noscience
For som tyme lady Er men preye to the
Thou goste byforne of thyn benygnyte

l.hi: And getest vs vnto þin sone so clere

div.l: Myne konnyng is to wayke O blisful quyene
For to declare thin grete worthinesse
That I ne may the weyght nought sustene
But as achild of xij . monthe elde or lesse
That can vnnethes and word expsse
Right so fare I and therfore I ȝou preye
Gydeth my song þat I schal of ȝou seye
THer was in Acye in a gret Cite
Amonges Crysten folk ⁊and Iewerye
Susteyned by a lord of þat countre
For foule vsure and lucre of vylanye
Hatful to Crist and to his companye
And thurgh the strete man myght ryde or wende

l.hi: For hit was fre and open at euery ende

div.l: A lytel scole of Crysten folk ther stood
Doun at þe ferther ende in whiche þ̉er were
Children an hepe I come of Crystes blood
That lernd in þat scole ȝere by ȝere
Suche mane doctⁱne as men vsed þere
This is to say syngen and to rede

l.hi: As smale children done in her childehede

div.l: Among þis children was a wydowes sone
A lytel Clergioun vij . ȝere of age
That day be day to scole was his wone
And eke also where he sawh the ymage
Of Crystes moder hadde he in vsage
As him was taught to knele a doun and seye

l.hi: Hys Aue marye as he goth by þe weye

div.l: Thus hath þis wydewe her lytil childe taught
Oure blesful lady Cristes moder dere
To worschip ay and he for gat it nought
For sely child wol alday sone lere
But ay when I remembre me on this matere
Seynt Nycholas stant euyr in my psence

l.hi: For he so ȝonge to Crist ded Reuerence

div.l: This childe his lytel boke lernynge
As he satte in þe scole at his prymere
He Alma redemptoris herd synge
As children lernd her antyphoner
And as he durste he drowe him nere ⁊and nere
And herkened ay þe wordes and þe note

l.hi: Til he the firste vers couthe al by rote

div.l: Nouȝt wiste he what þe latyn was to say
For he so ȝonge and tender was of age
But on a day his felawe gan he preye
To expounen him this songe in his langage
Or tellen him whi þis songe was in vsage
Thus preyde he hym to construe and declare

l.hi: Ful ofte tyme vp on his knees bare

div.l: His felawe whiche elder was then he
Answerid him thus this sang I haue herd saye
Was maked of oure blisful lady free
Hire to salue and eke hire for to preye
To ben oure help ⁊and socoure when we deye
I can no more expoune in þis matere

l.hi: I lerne songe I can but smale gramere

div.l: And is þis songe I made in reuerence
Of cristes moder sayde þis Innocent
Now certes I wol do my diligence
To konne hit Er Cristemas be went
Thow that I for my prymere shal be shent
And schal be betyn thryes in an houre

l.hi: Y wole hit konne oure lady for to honoure

div.l: His felawe taught him homward pryuyly
Fro day to day til he couthe hit by rote
And þenne he sange hit wel and boldely
Froward to word acordynge to þe note
Thries on aday hit passeth thurgh his throte
To scoleward and homward when he went

l.hi: On cristes moder sette was his entent

div.l: As I haue sayde thurgh out þe Iewerye
This lytel childe as he cam to and fro
Ful meryly then wolde he synge and crye
On Alma Redemptoris euermo
The swetnes hath his hert ꝑperced so
Of Cristes moder that to hure to pye

l.hi: He can nought stynte of syngynge by þe weye

div.l: Oure ferste foo the ʆserpent Sathanas
That hath in Iewes his waspes neste
Vp swalle and sayde O Ebrayke peple alas
Ys this a thing to ȝow that is honeste
That suche aboy shal walken as him leste
In ȝoure despyte ⁊and syngen of suche sentence

l.hi: Whiche is aȝayn ȝoure lawes reuerence

div.l: Fro thennes forth the Iewes han conspired
This Innocent out of þis world to chace
In homycydye ther to han thei huyred
That in an aley had a pryuy place
And as þe child gan for by forto pace
This cursed Iewe hym hent and held faste

l.hi: And kutte his throte and in a putte him caste

div.l: I say that in a wardrope thei him threwe
Where as þis Iewes purgen Entraille
O cursed folk of herowdes al newe
What may ȝoure euel tent ȝou avayle
Mordre wol out certeyn hit wole nought fayle
And namly þere honoure of god shuld sprede

l.hi: The blood out cryeth on ȝoure cursed dede

div.l: O Martyr souded to vyrgynyte
Now mayst thow syngen folwyng eủer in one
The white lambe Celestial quod he
Of whiche þe grete Euᵃngelist seynt Iohn
In pathmos wrote whiche saith þei þat gon
By forne this lambe and syng a song al newe

l.hi: That neuer fleschly wēmmen they knewe

div.l: This pore wydewe wayteth al þat nyght
After þis lytel childe but hom cam nought
For whom assone as hit was dayes lyght
With face pale for drede and besy þought
She hath at scole and elles where him sought
Tylle fynally sche gan so fer aspye

l.hi: That he was seyn laste in þe Iewerye

div.l: With modres pitee in hire herte enclosed
She goth as thowȝ sche were half out of mynde
To euery place where she hath supposed
By lykly hede her Childe to fynde
And euer on cristes moder meke and kynde
She cryed and at þe laste thus she wrought

l.hi: Among þe cursed Iewes sche him sought

div.l: She freyneth and she preyeth pytously
To Euery Iewe þat dwelt in thilke place
To telle hire if her Child went hem by
They seyden nay but Ihc of his grace
Ȝaff in hire thought in with alitel space
That in that place after her sone she cryed

l.hi: Ther he was caste in a putte bysyde

div.l: O grete god þat ꝑperfourmed thin laud
By mouthe of Innocense lo here þyn myght
Thys gēmme of chastyte this Emerawd
And eke of martirdome the ruby bryght
Ther he with throte I korue lay vp ryght
He Alma redemptoris gan to synge

l.hi: So longe þat alle the place gan to rynge

div.l: The cristen folk that thurgh þe strete went
In camen for to wondren of this thinge
And hastely þey for þe prouost sent
He came anon with outen any tarying
And heryeth crist that is of heuen kyng
And eke his moder honoure of mankynde

l.hi: And after þat þe Iewes let he bynde

div.l: This child with pitous lamentacioıı̄un
Vp taken syngyng his song alway
And with honoure and grete ꝓprocessiou
They Caryen him to þe next Abbay
Hys moder swownynge by the bere lay
Vnnethes myght þe peple that was there

l.hi: This newe rachel bringe fro his bere

div.l: With turment and with shameful deth ilkone
This prouost doth thise Iewes forto sterue
That of þis mordre wist and that anone
He nolde none suche cursednes obserue
Euel shal haue þat euyl wol deserue
Therfore with wilde hors he ded hem drawe

l.hi: And after that he hinge hem by þe lawe

div.l: Vpon þis bere ay lith þis Innocent
By forn þe chief auter whyles mas last
And after þat the Abbot with his Couent
Hadde sped hem for to burye him faste
And when þey halywater on him caste
Ȝet spake þe childe whan spreynt was þe holywater

l.hi: And sang O Alma redemptoris mater

div.l: This Abbot whiche þat was an holy man
As Monkes be or elles ouȝten to be
This ȝonge child to couire he by gan
And saide O dere Child I hailse the
By vertu of þe holy Trynyte
Telle me what is thi cause forto synge
Sethyns þat þi þrote is kutte at my semynge
My throte is kutte vnto my nekke bon
Saide þis childe and as by way of kynde
I shuld haue deyed ȝe lang tyme agon
But Ihıı̄un crist as ȝe in bokes fynde
Wol þat his glorie last ⁊and be in mynde
And for þe worshipe of hys moder dere

l.hi: Ȝet may I synge O Alma loud and clere

div.l: This welle of mercy Cristes moder swete
I loued alwey as after my konnynge
And when þat I my lyf shulde lete
To me she cam and bade me for to synge
This anteme verryly in my mynde deynge
As ȝe haue herd and when þat I hadde songe

l.hi: Me thought she leyde a greyn vpon my tonge

div.l: Wherfore I synge and synge mote certeyn
In honoure of þe blisful martir fre
Til of my tonge of taken is þe greyn
And after þat seide she thus to me
Myn lytil childe now wole I fecche þe
When þat þy greyn is fro þyn tonge I take

l.hi: Be nought agast I wole þe nought forsake

div.l: This holy monk this Abbot him mene I
Hys tunge ouht caught ⁊and toke awey þe greyn
And he ȝaff vp the gost ful softely
And when þe Abbot had this wonder seyn
His salt teres stryked doun as reyn
And gruff he fel al plat to the grounde

l.hi: And stille he lay as he had ben I bounde

div.l: The Couent eke lay vpon þe pauyment
Wepyng and herying Cristes moder dere
And after þat þey ryse and forth ben went
And toke away þis martir fro his bere
And in a tombe of marbill stones clere
Enclosyn þey his lytil body swete
Ther he is now god leue vs for to mete
O ȝong hewe of lincolle slayn also
With cursed Iewes as hit is notable
For hit nys but alytel while ago
P̉reye eke for vs we synful folk vnstable
Þat of his mercye god so mcyable
On vs his grete mercy multeplye
For reuerence of his moder marye
The ꝓprolog of ʆsir thopas
WHan ended was þis tale eủery man
As sobre was þat wonder it was to see
Til þat oure ooste Iapen to by gan
And then at Erst he loked vpon me
And sayde thus what man art þou qd he
Thow lokest as þogh þou woldest fynde an hare
For euere vpon þe grounde I see the stare
Approche nere and loke meryly
Now ware ȝe sires and lete þis man haue place
He in þe wast is shapen as wel as I
This were a popet in armes to embrace
For any wōmman smal and faire of face
He semeth eluysche by his contynaunce
For vnto no wight doth he dalyaunce
Say now somwhat sethyns oþ̉er folk han sayde
Telle vs a tale of myrthe and þat anon
Oost qd he ne be not euel apayde
For other tale certes can I noon
But of a Ryme I lerned long agoon
Ȝe þat is good qd he now shul we here
Som deynte thing me thinkeþ by his chere
Here endith the prolog //
And begynneth the tale
LEsteneth lordes in good entent
And I wil telle verrayment
Of myrthe and of Salace
Al of a knyght was faire and gent
In Bataille and in tornament
His name was sire Thopace
I born he was in fer contree
In flaundres all by ȝonde þe see
At Poperynge in the place
His fader was aman ful free
And lord he was of þat contree
As hit was goddes grace
Sire Thopas was a doughty swayn
White was his face as payndemayn
His lippes rede as Rose
Hys rode is lyke scarlet in grayn
And I ȝou telle in good certayn
He hadde a semely nose
Hys here his berd was lyke safroun
That to his gyrdel raughte adoun
Hys shon of Cordewayn
Of brugges were his hosyn broıı̄un
Hys robe waas of Cyclatoun
That coste many a Iayne
He couthe hunte at þe wylde dere
And ryde on haukynge for þe ryuer
With greye goshauke on honde
Ther to he was a good Archere
To wrastelyng was þer none his pere
Ther any man shuld stonde
Ful many a mayde bright in bour
They mourne for his ꝑparamour
When þey were bette to slepe
But he was chaste ⁊and no lecchour
And swete as is þe bremble flour
That bereth þe rede hepe
And so byfel vpon a Day
For sothe as I ȝow telle may
Sire Thopas wolde oute ryde
He worthe vpon his stede gray
And in his hand a launce gay
A long swerd by his syde
He priketh thorw a fayre foreste
Ther Inne is many a wilde beste
Ye bothe bukke and hare
And as he pryketh north ⁊and Est
I telle ȝou him hadde almest
By tydde a Sory care
Ther spryngen herbes grete ⁊and smale
The lyquoryce and the setuale
And many a clowe giloffre
And notemigges to putte in ale
Wheþer hyt be moyst or stale
Or forto leye in Cofre
The bryddes synge it is no nay
The sꝑparhauke and þe popyngeay
That Ioye hit was to here
The þrustelcok made eke his lay
The wode doufe vpon þe spray
Sche sang ful loude and clere
Sire Thopas fel in loue longyng
And when he herd þe þrustel syng
He pryked as he were wood
Hys faire stede in hys prykyng
So swette þat men myghte hym wrynge
Hys sydes weren all blood
Sire Thopas eke so wery was
For prykynge on the softe gras
So fiers was his corage
That dou he leyde him in þat place
To maken his his stede som solace
For he was so sauage
O seynt Marye benedicite
What eyleth þis loue at me
To bynde me so sore
Me dremed all þis nyght parde
An Elf queene schal my lēmman be
And slepe vnder my gore
An Elf queene wole I loue I wys
For in þis world no wōmman ys
Worthy to be my make /
In towne
All other wōmmen I forsake
And to an Elf quene I me betake
By dales and eke by downe
In to hys sadel he cam anon
And pryketh ouer style and stoon
An Elf queene for to aspye
Til he so long hath ryden ⁊and goon
That he fonde in a pryuy woon
The contre of fayrye /
so wilde
For in that contre nas þer none
Neyther wyf ne childe
Til him þer cam a ioly geaıı̄unt
His name was cleped sire Olyphant
A ꝑperilous man of dede
He seyde child by tirmagant
But ȝif þou pryke out of myn hant
Anoon I slee thy stide /
with mace
Here is þe quene of fairye
With harpe and pipe ⁊and Symphonie
Dwellyng in this place
The childe saide so mote I the
To morwe wil I meten the
When I haue myn Armure
And ȝit I hope ꝑpar ma fay
Þat þow shalt with þis launcegay
Abyen hit ful sore /
thorgh þy mawe
Schal I ꝑperce ȝif þat I may
Or it be fully pryme of day
For here þou schalt be slawe
Sire Thopas drow a bak ful faste
This geaunt at him stones caste
Out of a fel staf slynge
But faire askapeth child thopace
And alle it was þorgh goddes grace
And þorw his faire berynge
Ȝet lesteneth lordes to my tale
Murier þen þe nyghtyngale
For now I wole ȝou rowne
How sire Thopas with sydes smale
Prykyng oủer down and dale
I come agayn to towne
His mery men comanded he
To make him boþe game ⁊and glee
For nedes moste he fyghte
With a geaıı̄unt wiþ hede thre
For ꝑparamour and Iolyte
Of oon that schon ful bryght
Do come he seyde myn mynstrales
And gestoured for to telle vs tales
A noon in myn armyng
Of Romaıı̄unces that ben reales
Of popes and of Cardenales
And eke of loue lykyng
They fet hym ferst þe swete wyn
And liquorice and eke comyn
With sugre þat is trye
He dide next his white lere
Of cloth of lake fyn and clere
A briche and eke a sherte
And next his sherte and aketou
And ouer þat an habergon
For ꝑpersynge of his herte
And ouer þat a fyn hauberk
Was al I wrought of Iewes werk
Ful strong hyt was of plate
And ouer that his cote Armure
As white as is þe lylye floure
In whiche he wolde debate
Hys schild was al of gold so rede
And þer ynne was a bores hede
A charbokil by syde
And þere he swore on ale and bred
That þe geaunt schulde be deed
Betyde what so be tyde
His Iambes were of qurboyly
His swerdes scheþe of yuory
His helm of laton bryght
His sadil was of Ruel bon
Hys brydel as the sonne schoon
Or as þe mone so light
Hys spere was of fyne cypres
That bodeth werre ⁊and no thing pees
The hede ful sharpe I groıı̄unde
Hys steede was al dappel gray
Hit gooth an amble by þe way
Ful softely ⁊and round /
In londe
Lordes myn here a fytte
Ȝif ȝe wole eny more of hitte
To telle hit wole I fonde
Now holdeth ȝoure mouth ꝑpar charite
Bothe knyght and lady free
And herkeneth to my spelle
Of batayle and of chyualrye
And of ladyes loue drerye
Anone I wol ȝou telle
Men speke of romaunces of prys
Of hornchild and of ypotys
Of Beves and of Sire gy
Of sire libeus ⁊and pleyndamour
But sire Thopas he bereth þe flour
Of real Chyualrye
His good stede al he be strod
And forth vpon his way he rood
As sparcles out of þe bronde
Vpon his crest he bar a toure
And there ynne styked a lylye flour
God shylde his corps fro schonde
And for he was a knyght aunterous
He nolde slepen in none hous
But lyggen in his hoode
His bryght helm was his wanger
And by hym bayteth his destrer
Of herbes fyne and goode
Explicit
The prolog of Mellibe
NO more of this for goddes dignite
Quod oure oost for þou makest me
So wery of þin lewdenes
That also wisly god me bles
Myn eres ake of thi darsty speche
Now suche a ryme þe deuel I be teche
This may be wel ryme dogerell qd he
Whi so qd I why wilt þou lette me
More of my tale than an other man
Sethyns it is þe beste ryme I can
By god qd he pleynly I the say
Thou shalt no longer rymen here to day
Thow dost noght elles but dyspendest tyme
Sire oo word þou shalt no lenger ryme
Let see wheþ̉er þou canst telle ought in geste
Or telle in prose somwhat at þe leste
In whiche þ̉er be sōmme merthe ⁊and som doctⁱne
Gladly quod I by goddes swete pyne
I wil ȝou telle a litel thing in prose
That oughte lyke ȝou as I suppose
Other elles certes ȝe ben to daungerous
Hit is a moral tale vertuous
Al be hit tolde somtyme in sundry wyse
Of sondry folk as I shal ȝou deuyse
As þus ȝe wote wel eủery euᵃngeliste
Þat telleth vs of Ihıı̄un Crist
Ne saith not al þing as his felawe doth
But natheles her sentence is al soth
And alle accorden as in her sentence
Al be ther in her tellynge difference
For some of hem seyn more ⁊and sōmme seyn lesse
When þey his pitous passioıı̄un expsse
I mene of Marc Matheu luke and Iohn
But douteles her sentence is al on
þ̉erfore lordynges alle ȝou beseche
Ȝif þat ȝe þinke I varye in my speche
As þus ȝif þat I telle somwhat more
Of ꝓprouerbes þen ȝe haue herd by fore
Comprehendid in þis litel tretys here
To enforce with þe effecte of my matere
And þoughe I nadde þe same wordes saye
As ȝe han herd ȝit to alle ȝou I praye
Blameth me not for as in myn sentence
Ȝe schal not fynden moche difference
For þe sentence of þe tretys lyte
After þe whiche þis mery tale I wryte
And herkeneth what I schal seye
And lete me telle my tale I preye
Here endith the prolog //

div.ab: And begynneþ the tale of Melibe

A yong man whilom celled Melibe myghti and
ryche bygat vpon his wyf þat called was pru
dence a doughter whiche þat cleped Sapience .

Vpon a day fel þat he for his disport is went
in to þe feldes him to pleye
