div.l: And here begynneth the prolog of the Monkes tale
Whanne ended was þe tale of Mellibe
And of hire prudence ⁊and of hire benygnite
Oure oost seide as I am feiþful man
And by þat pcious body madrian
I had leủere þan a barelle ale
That good leef my wif had herd þis tale
Sche nys no thing of suche pacience
As was þis Mellibeus wif prudence
By goddes bones whan I bete my knaues
Sche bringeth me þe grete clobbid staues
And crieth slee þe dogges eủerychon
And breke hem bothe bak and bon
And ȝif þat eny neighebore of myne
Wol noght in chirche to my wif enclyne
Or be so hardy hire to trespace
Whan sche cometh home sche rıı̄unpeth in my face
And crieth false coward wreke þi wyf
By corpus bones I wol haue þi knyf
And þou schalt haue my distaf ⁊and goo spynne
Fro day to nyght right þus she wol by gynne
Alas sche seith þat euere I was I schape
To wedde a melk sop or a coward ape
Þat wol ben ouerlad of eủery wight
Thou durst not stonde by þi wyfes right
This is my lif but ȝif þat I wole fight
And out at þe dore anon I mote me dighte
Or elles I nam but lost but ȝif þat I
Be lyke a wilde lyou fool hardy
I wote wel sche wol doo me slee some day
Some neighebor and þan go my way
For I am ꝑperilous with knyf in honde
Al be hit þat I dar not hire withstonde
For sche is bigge in Armes by my feith
Þat schal he fynde þat hire mysdoth or seith
But lat vs passe from þis matere
My lord þe monk quod he be merye of chere
For ȝe schole telle a tale trewely
Loo Rouchestre stont here faste by
Ryde forth myn owne lord breke not oure game
But by my trewþe I can noght ȝoure name
Wheþer schal I calle ȝou my lord dan Iohn
Or daun Thomas or elles dan Albon
Of what hous be ȝe by ȝoure fader kyn
I vowe to god þou hast awel faire skyn
Hit is a ientel pasture þ̉ere þou goost
Þou art not lyke a penānnt or a goost
Vpon my feith þou art some officere
Som worthi sextyn or some celerere
For by my soule as to my doom
Þou art a maister whan þou art at hoom
Ne pore cloystrer ne no novys
But a goủernour wily and wys
And þ̉ere with alle of brawn ⁊and of bones
A wel faringe ꝑpersone for þe nones
O prey to god ȝeue him confusion
Þat þe broght ferst in to religion
Þou woldest han ben a tred foul aright
Haddest þou as grete aleue as þᵘ hast myght
To ꝑperfourme al þi luste in engendrure
Þou haddest bygeten many a creature
Alas whi werest þou so wyde a cope
God ȝeue me sorwe but and I were pope
Noght only þou but eủery myghti man
Þogh he were schore wel hye vp on his pan
Schulde haue a wif for alle þe world is lorn
Religiou hath taken vp al þe corn
Of tredyng and we borel men ben schrimpes
Of feble trees þ̉ere cometh wrecchid ympes
This maketh þat oure heires ben so sklendre
And feble þat þei may not wel engendre
This makith þat oure wyfes wolen assaye
Religious folk for ȝe may bettre paye
Of venus payementz þan may we
God woot no lusshebornes paien ȝe
But be noght wroth lord þoght þat I pleie
Wel ofte in game a soth I haue herd seie
THis worthi Monk took alle in pacience
And seide I wil done all my diligence
As fer as sowneth in to honeste
To telle ȝou a tale or two or thre
And ȝif ȝou leste to herken hiderward
I wil ȝou seyn þe lyf of Seynt Edward
Or elles ferst tragedies wol I telle
Of whiche I haue an hundred in my selle
Tragedie is to seyn a certeyn storie
As olde bookes maken vs memorie
Of him þat stod in grete ꝓprosꝑperite
And is fallen out hye degree
In to myserie and endith wrecchidly
And þey be vercified comōnnly
Of sixx feet whiche man clepen exametron
In prose eke ben endited many oon
And eke in metre mani a sondry wise
Loo þis declaringe may I now suffice
Now herkenith ȝif ȝou liketh for to here
But firste I ȝou beseke in þis matere
Þogh I by ordre telle noght þise þinges
Be hit of popes Emꝑperoure or kynges
After hir ages as men writen fynde
But telle some byfore some by hynde
As hit now comeþ in to my remēmbrānce
Haueþ me excused of myn ignorance
Here endith the //prolog
And begynneþ the tale
Wole be wayle in manere of tragedie >
The harm of hem þat stonden in hye degree
And fullen so þat þere was no remedye
To bringe hem out of hire aduersite
For certen whan þat fortune lest to fle
There may no man þe cours of hire with holde
Lat no man triste on blynde ꝓprosꝑperite
Beth war of þese emsamples trewe ⁊and olde
At lucifer þogh he an angel were
And not aman at him I wole be gynne
For þogh fortune may non aıı̄ungel dere
Fro hye degree ȝit fel he for his synne
Dou in to helle where he is ȝit Inne
O lucifer brightest of aıı̄ungels alle
Now art þou Sathanas þat mayst not twynne
Out of miserie in whiche þou art falle
Loo Adam in þe feld of damacene
With goddes owne fynger wroght was he
And no be getynge of mānis sperme vnclene
And welt all paradys savinge oo tree
Hadde neuere worldly man so hye degree
As Adam til he for his gouernance
Was dryuen out of hye prosperite
To laboure and to helle and meschaıı̄unce
Lo Sampson whiche was anıı̄unnciate
By þe Aungel longe er his natiuite
And was to god almyghti consecrate
And stood in nobles whiles he myghte see
Was neủere suche an other as was he
To speke of strengþe and þ̉erto hardynesse
But to his wyfes tolde he his secree
Þorgh whiche he slogh him for wrecchidnesse
Sampson þis noble and myghti champion
With outen wepen sauf his hondes tweie
He slowh and all to rent þe lyon
Toward his weddyng walkyng by þe weye
His false wyf couthe him so plese ⁊and preye
Til sche his conseil knewe ⁊and sche vntrewe
Vnto his foos his conseil gan be wreye
And him forsook and took an other newe
An hundred Foxes took sampson for Ire
And all her tayles he to geder bond
And sette þe foxes tailes al on a fyre
For he in eủery taille had putte a brond
And þey brend alle þe cornes in þat lond
And all her Olyues and her vynes eke
A thousand man eke he slowh with his hond
And hadde no wepene but an Asse cheke
¶ When þei were slayn so thersted him þat he
Was wel nyhe lorn for whiche he gan to preye
That god wolde of his peyne haue som pitee
And sende him drinke or elles moste he deie
And of þis Asse cheke þat was so druye
Out of a wang toth sprang anon a welle
Of whiche he drank I now schortly to seie
Thus hilpe him god as Iudicu can telle
By verray force at Gasan on a nyght
Mawgre philistiens of þat citee
The gate of þe toıı̄unn he haþ vp plight
And on his bak I caried hem haþ he
Hyghe on an hille where as men myghte see
O noble almyghty Sampson leef and dere
The stronge and noble hath be
In all þis worlde ne hadde þ̉ere ben þi pere
¶ This Sampson neủer cyder drank ne wyn
Ne on his heed came rasour none ne schere
By pcepte of þe messanger devyn
For all his strengþe lay in his here
And fully twenty ȝere by ȝere
He hadde of Israel þe goủernaıı̄unce
But after sone schal he wepe many a teere
For wōmmen schulen bringen him to Mischance
Vnto his lēmman Dalida he tolde
That in his heris all his strengþe lay
And falsely to his fomen sche him solde
And Slepynge vpon hir barme vpon a day
Sche made to clippe or schere his here a way
And made his fomen all his crafte aspyen
And when þat þey him fond in suche Array
Þei band him faste and put oute boþe his eighen
¶ But er his here was I clipped or I schaue
There was no band þat myghe him bynde
But now is he in pⁱrison putte in a kaue
Where as þei made him at þe querne grynde
O noble sampson strengest of mankynde
O whilom Iuge in glorie and richesse
Now maist þou wepe with thyn eighen blynde
Sithen þou art fro wele falle in to wrecchidnese
¶ The ende of þis caitif was as I schal seie
His fomen made a feste vpon a day
And made him as her foole by forn hem pleie
And þis was at þe temple of a grete aray
But at þe laste he made a foule affray
For he two postes schoke ⁊and made hem falle
And doun fel temple and all þere it lay
And slough him self and eke his fomen alle
This is to say þe pⁱrinces eủerichon
And eke a þowsand bodyes were þ̉ere slayn
With fallyng of þe grete temple of ston
Of Sampson ne wole I nomore sayn
Beth war of þis ensample olde ⁊and playn
That no men telle his conseil til here wyfes
Of suche þing as þei wolde haue secre fayn
Ȝif þat it touche her lymes or here lyfes
>OF Ercule þe soủeraigne conquerour
Syngen his werkes lewed ⁊and hye renou
For in his tyme of strengþe he bar the flour
He slowhe and rafte þe skyn fro þe lyon
He of Sentaures leide þe boste a dou
He Arpyes slowhe þe cruel briddes felle
He golden apples rafte þe dragon
He drowe our serberois þe hound of helle
¶ He slowhe þe cruel tyraunt Buserus
And made his hors to frete him flesche ⁊and boon
He slowh þe v̉erray serpent venymous

And he slowh Cacus in a cave of stoon
He slowh þe geaunt antheus þe stronge
He slow þe Grisly bore ⁊and þat anoon

Was neủere wight sithen þe world bygan
Þat slowh so many monstres as ded he
Thorgh out þis wilde world his mane ran
What for his strengþe and for his bounte
And eủery Reem went For to see
He was so stronge þat no man myghte him lette
At bothe þe worldes ende saith trophe
In stede of bondes he a pyler sette
A lēmman hadde þis noble champion
That hight dyaniyre fresche as may
And as þe clerkes maken mencion
Sche hath him sent a scherte fresche ⁊and gay
Alas þis scherte and weilaway
Envenymed was subtilly wiþ alle
That or þat he had wered it half a day
Hit made his bones fro his flesche to falle
But natheles som clerk her excusen
By oon þat highte nessus þat it maked
Be as be may I wol hire noght accusen
But on his bak the scherte he weres al naked
Til þat his flesche was for þe venym blaked
And when he sawh noon other remedye
In hote coles hath he him self raked
For with no venym deyned he to dye
Thus starf this worthi myghti hercules
Loo who may truste on fortune any throwe
For him þat folowiþ all þis world of prees
Or he be war is ofte I leide ful lowe
Ful wys is he þat him self knowe
Beth war for when þat fortune lest to glose
Then waiteth sche her man dou to þrowe
By suche a wey as he wolde leste suppose
the myghti throne þe pcious tresoure
The glorious septer and real mageste
That hed þe kynge Nabugodosor
With tunge vnnethe may discryued be
He twyes nam Ierlm the Citee
The vessel of þe temple he with him ladde
At Babiloyne was his soủerayn see
In whiche his glorie ⁊and his delite he hadde
The fayrest children of þe blood royal
Of Ierlm he dide doo gilde anoon
And maked eche of hem to ben his charl
Amonge all oþer Danyel was oon
That was þe wisest child of eủerichon
For he þe dremes of þe kyng expowned
Where as in Caldey clerk was þer noon
That wiste to what fyn his dremes sowned

To whiche ymage boþe ȝonge and olde
Comaıı̄unded he to loute and haue in drede
Or in a fourneys ful of flāmmes rede
He schal be brent þat wolde noght obeie
But neủere wolde assente to þat dede
Danyel ne his ȝonge felawes tweie
This kynge of kynges proude ⁊and Elate
He wende þat god þat sitte in mageste
Ne myght him not by reue of his estate
But sodeynly he loste his dignyte
And like a beste him semed for to be
And ete hey as an oxe and lay þ̉eroute
In reyn with wilde bestes walked he
Til certeyn tyme was come aboute
And I lyke an Egles fethres was his heres
His nayles lyke briddes Clawes were
God releued him a certeyn ȝeres
And ȝaf him witte and þan with many a tere

And or þat tyme I leide was on his bere

>His sone whiche þat highte Baltizar
That helde þe regne after his fader day
He by his fader couthe not be war
For proude of he was of herte ⁊and of array

His hyghe Estate assured him in pryde
But fortune cast him doun ⁊and þ̉er he lay

A feste he made vnto his lordes alle
Vpon a tyme he made hem blithe be
And then his officers gan he calle
Goth bringeth forth þe vessels qd he
Whiche þat my fader in his ꝓprosꝑperite
Out of þe temple of Ierlm by rafte
And to oure hye goddes þanke we

His wyf his lordes ⁊and his concubynes

And on a wal this kyng his eyen kaste
And sawe an hand armles þat wroot ful faste

In al þat lond Magicien was þer non

And saide kyng god to þi fader sent
Glorie and honour Regne tresoure ⁊and rent
And he was proude ⁊and no þing god ne dradde

With Assis was his hīntaciou
And ete hey as a beste in wete ⁊and drye
Til þat he knewe by grace ⁊and by renou
That god of heuene hath duāmciou
Ouer eủery regne and euery creature
And þanne had god of him compassion

And knowest al þese þinges pⁱriuely
And art Rebel to god and art his foo

Thy wyf eke ⁊and thyn wenches synfully

And heried false goddes cursedly
Therfore to þe schapen grete peyne is
This hand was sent fro god þat on þe wal
Wrote Mane thechel phares truste me
Thyn regne is done þou weyest not at al
Deuyded is thi regne and hit schal be
To medes and to ꝑperces ȝeuen quod he
And þilke same nyght þe kyng was slawe
And Darius occupieth his degree
Thei he þ̉erto had neyther right ne lawe
Lordinges herby ensample may ȝe take
How þat in lordschip is no sikernesse
For whenne fortune wil a man forsake
He beryþ a wey his regne and his richesse
And eke his frendes boþe more and lesse
And what man hath frendis þorgh fortune
Mishap wole make hem enemyes I gesse
This ꝓprouerbe is ful soth and ful comune
CEnobia of palymer the queene
As writen ꝑpersyens of hire noblesse
So worthi was in Armes and so kene
Þat no wight passid hir in hardynesse
Ne in lynage ne in other gentilnesse
Of kynges blood of ꝑperce is sche descended
I say þat sche nad most fairnesse
But of hir schap sche myght not be amended
Fro childhode I fynde þat sche fledde
Office of wōmmen and in to wode sche went
And many a wild hertes blood sche schedde
With Arwes brode þat sche to him sente
She was so swift þat sche anon hem hente
And whan þat sche was elder sche wolde kille
Lyoıı̄uns liberdes and beres al to rent
And in her Armes welde hem at her wille
Sche dorste wide bestes dennes seke
And renne in þe montaynes all þe nyght
And slepe vnder a bussche sche couthe eke
Wrastlen by verray force and myght
With eny ȝonge man were he neủere so wight
Ther myght no þing in hire armes stonde
Sche kepte hire mayden hode from eủery wight
To no man deyned hire to be bonde
But at þe laste hire frendes han hir maried
To Odonak a prince of þat citee
Al were it so þat sche hem longe taried
And ȝe schal vnderstonde how þat he
Had suche fantasies as had sche
But natheles when þei were knet in fere
Thei lyueden in Ioye and in felicite
For eche of hem had other lief and dere
Saue oo þing þat sche nolde neủere assent
By no wey þat he schulde by hire lye
But ones for hit was hire pleyne entent
To haue a childe þe worlde to multeplie
And al so sone as sche myght aspye
That sche was noght with childe with þat dede
Than wole sche suffre him done his fantasie
Eft sone and not but ones out of drede
And ȝif sche were with childe at þilke caste
No more schulde he pleie thilke game
Til fourty dayes were paste
Than wolde sche ones suffre him do þe same
All were þis Odonak wilde or tame
He gate no more of hire for þus sche saide
Hit was to wyfes leccherie and schame
In other cas ȝif þat men with hem plaide
Two sones by þis Odenak had sche
The whiche sche kepte in vertu ⁊and in lettrure
But now vnto oure tale torne we
I say þat worschipful creature
And wise þer with and large with mesure
So penyable in werre and curteys eke
No more laboure myght in werre endure
Was none þey all þis world me schulde seke
Hire riche array myght noght be tolde
As wel in vessel as in clothinge
Sche was al clad in perre and in gold
And eke sche lafte noght for none huntynge
To haue of sondry tonges folk knowyng
Whan þat sche leiser had and forto entende
To lerne bokes was al hire lykyng
How sche in vertu myght hire lyf dispende
And schortly of þis story forto entrete
So doughti was hire housband as sche
That thei conquered many regnes grete

Apꝑpertenant vnto þe mageste

Ay whiles þat Odenak dayes laste

And how þat alle þe processe felle in dede
Whi sche conquered and what take had þ̉erto

How þat sche was byseged and I take
Lete him vnto my maister petrak goo
That writte I now of this I vndertake
When Odenak was dede sche myghtily
The regnes held and with hir ꝓpropre hond
A gayn hire foos sche faught trewely
That þer nas kyng ne pⁱrince in all þat lond
Þat he nas glad ȝif he þat grace fond
Þat sche ne wolde vpon his land werreye
With hire þey made alliance be bond
To ben in pees and lete hire ride and pleye
The Emꝑperour of Rome Claudius
Ne hym by forne þe Romayn galyene
Ne dorste neủere be so Coragius

Ne Surriene ne none Arabiene
With Inne the feld þat dorste with hire fight
Lest þat sche wold with hire hondes him slen
Or with her meyne putten hem to flight
In kynges Abite wente hire sones also
As heyres of her regnes alle
And hermanno and Tymalito
Here names were as ꝑperciens hem calle
But fortune hath ay in hir hony galle
This myghti quene may no while endure
Fortune out of hire regne made her to falle
To wrecchidnesse and to mysauenture
Aurelyon when þat þe goủernance
Of Rome came in to his hondes tweie
He schope vpon þis quene to do vengeance
And with his legioıı̄uns he toke his weie
Toward Cenobye and schortly forto seie
He made hire flee and at þe laste hir hente
And fetrid hire and eke hire children tweie
And wan the lond and home to Rome þei wente
Among these other þinges þat he wan
Here chare þat wroght with gold was ⁊and perre
This grete Romayn þis Aurelian
Hath with him lad for þat men scholde see
By forne his triumphe walketh sche
With gilt chaynes of her nek hanginge
Coroned sche was as after here degree
And ful of perry charged her clothinge
Alas fortune sche þat whilom was
Dredful to kynges and to Emꝑperoures
Now gaureth alle þe peple on hire alas
And sche þat helmes was in starke stoures
Shal on hire hede now bere a vitremyte
And sche þat bare þe Septer ful of floures
Schal bere a distaf hire cost for to quyte
O Noble o worthi petre glorie of spayne
Whom fortune held so hye in mageste
Wel oughte men thi pitous deth compleyne
Thi bastard broþer made the to flee
And after at a siege by subtillite
Thou were betraied and lad to his tente
Where as he wiþ his owne hond slow the
Succedinge in thi regne and in thi rente
The feld of snow with þe Egle of bak þ̉erynne
Caught with þe lyme rod coloures as þe glede
He brew þis cursidnesse and all þe synne
The wikked neste was werkere of þis nede
Noght charles Olyuere þat ay toke good hede
Of trouthe and honour but Armorekke
Genilou Olyủer corupte for mede
Broughtest þis worthi kyng in suche brekke
Worthi petre kyng of Cipre Also
That alisaundre wan be highe maistrie
Ful many an hethen wroghtest þou ful woo
Of whiche þyn owne lieges had envie
And for no þing but for thi Chiualrie
Thei in thi bed had slayn þe by þe morwe
Thus can fortune goủerne and gye
And out of ioye bringe in to sorwe
Of Melane grete Barnabo viscounte
God of delyte ⁊and scourge of lumbardie
Whi schulde not I thi fortune acounte
Sithen in Estate þou clomben were so hye
Thyn broþer sone þat was thi double allye
For he thi nevewe was and sone in lawe
With Inne his pⁱrisone made the to dye
But whi ne how wote I þat þou were slawe
Of þe Erle hugelyne of pyse the langoure
Ther may no tunge telle for pitee
But litel out of pyse stant a toure
In whiche in prisoıı̄un put was he
And with him ben his litel children thre
The eldest skarsly fyue ȝere was of age
Allas fortune it was grete cruelte
Suche briddis for to putte in suche a cage
Dampned he was to dye in þat prison
For Rog whiche þat bischop was of pise
Had on him made a false suggestion
Þurgh whiche þe peple gan on him aryse
And putten him to prison in suche a wise
As ȝe haue herd ⁊and mete ⁊and drinke he hadde
And þ̉er with al it was ful pore and badde
On a day byfel þat in þat houre
Whan þat his mete was wont to be broght
The gaillour schette þe dores of þe tour
He herde it wel but he sawh it noght
And in his herte anon þer fel a thoght
That þey for hunger wolde don him deien
Alas qd he alas þat I was wroght
Ther with þe teres fel fro his eighen
His ȝonge sone thre ȝere was of age
Vnto him seide : Fader whi do ȝe wepe
When wole þe gaillour bringe oure potage
Is þere no morsel brede þat ȝe do kepe
I am so hongey þat I may not slepe
Now wold god þat I myght slepen eủere
Then schulde non hungre in my body crepe
Ther is no thing sauf brede þat me were leủere
Thus day by day þe chile gan to crie
Til in his fadres barme adou hit lay
And seide fare we fader I mote deye
And kissed his fader and deide þe same day
And whan þe woful fader dede him say
For woo his armes two he gan to byte
And seide allas fortune and weylawey
Thyn fals whele my wo I may al wyte
His children wende þat hit for hunger was
Þat he his armes gnowe and noght for woo
And saiden fader do noght to allas
But rather ete þe flesche vpon vs two
Oure flesche þou ȝaue vs take oure flesche vs fro
And ete I now right thus to him þei saide
And after þat with ynne a day or two
Thei leide hem down in his lappe and deide
Him self dispeired eke for hunger starf
Thus ended is þe myghti Erle of pyse
Fro hye estat fortune fro him karf
Of his tregedie it ought I now suffise
Who so wole here it in a lenger wyse
Redeth þe grete poete of Itayle
That highte . Daunt ; for he can hit deuyse
Fro poynt to poynt noght oo word wole he faile
All þough þat Nero were as vicious
As any fend þat lieth ful low a dou
Ȝit he as telleth vs Swetheneus
This wide world had in subieccion
Bothe Est and West and Septemptrioıı̄un
Of rubies zaphires and of ꝑperles white
Were all his clothes browded vs ond dou
For he in gēmmes grete gan delite
More delicate more pompous of Array
More proude was neủere imꝑperour þan he
That ilke cloth þat he had wered a day
After þat tyme he nolde hit neủere see
Nettes of gold threde had he grete plente
To fisshen in Tibre when him list to pleye
His lustes as lawe in his degre
For fortune as his frende wolde him obeie
He Rome brent For his delicacie
The Senatoures he slowh vpon a day
To here how men wolde wepe and crye
And slowh his brother and by his suster lay
His moder made he in pitous array
For he her wombe slitte to byholde
Where he conceyued was so weylaway
That he so litel of his moder tolde
No tere out of his eighen for þat sight
Ne came but saide a faire wōmman was sche
Grete wonder is þat he couthe or myght
Be domesman of her dede beaute
The wyne to bringe comauded he
And drank anone noon oþ̉er woo he made
When myght is ioyned vnto cruelte
Alas to depe wole þe venym wade
In ȝouthe a maister had this Emꝑperour
To teche him lettrure and curtesie
For of moralyte he was the flour
As in his tyme but ȝif bokes lye
And whiles his maister had of him maistrye
He made him so cōnnynge and so souple
That longe tyme hit was or tyrannye
Or any vice in him dorste vncouple
This Seneca of whiche I devise
By cause Nero hadde of him suche drede
For he for vices wolde him chastise
Discretely as by word and noght by dede
Sire wolde he sayn an Emꝑperour mote nede
Be v̉ertuous and hate tyrannye
For whiche he him in bath made to blede
On bothe his armes til he moste dye
This Nero had eke of a Custumaıı̄unce
In ȝouthe aȝenst his maister for to rise
Whiche afterward him þoght a grete greuaıı̄unce
Therfore he made him deie in this wyse
But natheles þis Senek the wyse
Chees in a bath to deye in this mane
Rather þan han an other tormentise
And þus haþ Nero slayn his maister dere
Now felle hit so þat fortune lust no lenger
The hye pryde of Nero to cherice
For þogh he was strong ȝit was sche strenger
Sche þoght þus by god I am to nyce
To sette aman þat is fulfilled of vice
In hye degree an Emꝑperour him calle
By god out of his sete I wole him trice
When he leste weneth sounest schal he falle
The peple rose vpon him on anyght
For his defaute and when he it espied
Out of his dores anon he hath him dight
Allone and þere he wende had ben allied
He knokked faste and ay þe more he cryed
The faster schetten þei þe dores alle
Tho wiste he wel he had him self mys gyed
And wente his way no lenger dorste he calle
The peple cryede and rombled vp and dou
That with his eres herde he how þey seide
Where is þis false Traytour þis Neroıı̄un
For fere almost out of his witte abraide
And to his goddes pitously he saide
For socour but hit myght noght betyde
For drede of this him þoght þat he deyde
And ran in to a gardyn him to hyde
And in this gardyn fand he cherles tweie
That seten by a fyre ful greet and reed
And to þe Cherles tweie he gan to preye
To sleen him and to guerden of his heed
That to his body whēnne þat he were dede
Were no despite I done for his diffame
Hym self he slowh he couthe no better rede
Of whiche fortune lowh and made game
WAs neủere Captayne vnder a kyng
Þat regnes mo put in subiecciou
Ne strenger was in feld of all thing
As in his tyme nor gretter of renoıı̄un
Ne more pompous in hye psumpciou
Then Olypherne whiche fortune ay kiste
So lykerously and lad him vp and dou
Til þat his hed was of er that he wiste
Noght only þat þis world had of him awe
For lesynge of richesse and of liberte
But he made eủery man reneye his lawe
Nabugodonosor was lorde saide he
Non other god schulde honoured be
Aȝenst his heste no wight dar trespace
Sauf in Bethulia a stronge citee
Where Eliachim a preest was of þat place
But take kepe of þe deeth of Olyferne
Amydde his oste he dronke lay on a nyght
With ynne his tente large as is a berne
And ȝit for al his pompe and al his myght
Iudith a wōmman as he lay vp right
Slepynge his heued of smot ⁊and fro his tente
Ful pⁱriuely sche stale fro eủery wight
And in hire happe al sodeynly sche hente
What nedeth hit of kyng Antiochus
To telle his hye and real magestre
His hye pryde his werke venymous
For suche an other was neủere none as he
Redith whiche þat he was in Machabe
And redeth þe proude wordes þat he seide
And whi he fel fro his prosꝑperite
And in an halle how wrecchedly he deide
Fortune him had enhaunced so in pryde
That verrayly he wende he myght atteyne
Vnto þe sterres vpon on eủery side
And in a balaunce to weye þe moıı̄unteyne
And alle þe flodes of þe see restreyne
And goddes peple had he most in hate
Hem wolde he slee in torment and in peyne
Wenyng þat god ne myght his pride abate
And for þat Nichamour and Tymothe
With Iewes were venquisshed myghtily
Vnto þe Iewes suche an hate had he
That he hadde greithed his chaar ful hastifly
And swore and saide ful dispitously
Vnto Ierlm he wolde efte sone
To wreke his Ire on hyt ful cruelly
But of his purpos he was lette fulsone
God of his manace him so sore smote
With invisible woıı̄unde ay vncurable
That in his guttes karf so and bote
That his peynes were importable
And certeynly þe wrecche was resonable
For many mannes guttes ded he payne
But fro his purpos cursed and dampnable
For all his smerte he nolde hym restrayne
But bad anon apparaillen his Ooste
And sodeynly er he was of hit ware
God daunted all his pryde ⁊and all booste
For he so sore fel out of his chare
Þat hurte his lymes ⁊and his skyn to tare
So þat he ne myghte goo ne ryde
But in a chayer men aboute him bare
All for brused bothe bak and side
The wreche of god him smote so cruelly
That in his body wicked wormes crepte
And þerwiþ alle he stank so horribli
That none of alle his meyne þat him kepte
Whether so þat he woke or elles slepte
Ne myght not þe stynk of him endure
In this meschief he wailed and eke wepte
And knewe god lorde of euery creature
To all his oost and to him self also
Ful wlatsom was þe stynk of his careyne
No man myght him bere to ne fro
And in his stynke and in his horrible peyne
He starf ful wecchedly in a Monteyne
Thus hath þis robbour and homycide
That many aman made to wepe ⁊and pleyne
Suche guerdon as bilongeþ vnto pride
The storie of Alisaundre is so comune
That eủery wight þat haþ discrecion
Haþ herd somwhat or al of his fortune
This wide world as in conclusion
He wan bi strengþe or for his hye renoıı̄un
They weren glad for pees vnto him sende
The pride of man ⁊and beest he leide a dou
Where so he came vnto þe worldes ende
Comparisoıı̄un myght neủere be maked
Bytwixe him and an other conquerour
For al þis world for drede of him haþ quaked
He was of knyghode and of fredom floure
Fortune him made þe heire of hire honour
Saue wyn amd women no þing myght a swage
His highe entent in armes and labour
So was he ful of lovinge corage
What pitee were it to him þey I ȝou take
Of Darius and an hundred þousand moo
Of kynges pⁱrinces Erles bolde
Whiche he conquered and broght hem in to woo
I say as fer as man may ryde or goo
The world was his what schulde I more deuyse
For þogh I wryte and tolde ȝou eủere moo
Of hys knyghthode hit myght not suffise
Twelue ȝere he regned as seith Machabe
Philippes sone of Macedonie he was
Þat firste was kyng of Grece þe contree
O worthi gentil Alisaundre Alas
That eủere schulde falle suche acas
Enpoysoned of þi folk þou were
Thyn .s. fortune haþ torned in to an aas
And ȝit for the ne wepe sche neủere a tere
Who schal ȝeue teres man to compleyne
The deth of gentilnesse and of fraunchise
That al þe world welded in his demeyne
And ȝit him þoght it myght not suffice
So ful was his corage of highe empryse
Allas who schal me helpe to endite
False fortune and poysoıı̄un to despyse
The whiche two of all þis woo I wite
By wisdome manhede and by laboure
Fro humble hede and fro royal mageste
Vp ros he Iulius þe conquerour
That all þe occident by lond ⁊and see
By strengþe of hand or elles by trete
And vnto Rome made hem tributarie
And sethyns of Rome þe Emꝑperour was he
Til þat fortune wax his Adủersarie
O myghty Cesar that in tessalie
Aȝenst pompeus fader thyn in lawe
That of þe Orient had all þe Chiualrie
As fer as þat þe day bygynnyth dawe
Þeigh þorw thi knyghthode hast hem take ⁊and slawe
Saue fewe folk þat with pompeus fledde
Þorgh whiche þou puttest all þe Orient in awe
Thanke fortune þat so wel þe spedde
But now alitel while I wole bewayle
This pompeus þis noble goủernour
Of Rome whiche þat fleygh at þis bataile
I say oon of his men a fals traitour
His hede of smote to wynne him fauour
Of Iulius and him þe hede broghte
Alas pompeye of þe Orient conqueroᵘur
That fortune vnto suche a fynyte broghte
To Rome aȝein repaireth Iulius
With his triumphe laureate ful hyhe
But on a tyme Brutus Cassius
That euer had of his estate envie
Ful pⁱriuely had made conspiracie
A ȝenst þis Iulius in subtile wise
And caste þe place in whiche he scholde deie
With boydekyns as I schal ȝow devise
This Iulius to þe Capithole went
Vpon a day as he was wont to goon
And in the Capithole anon him hent
This fals Brutus and his foule foon
And styked him with boydekyns anon
With many a woıı̄unde and þus þey lete hym lye
But neủere gronte he at no strook but oon
Or elles at two bot ȝif his storie lye
So namly was þis Iulius of herte
And so wel loued estatly honeste
Þat þogh his didly woundes so sore smerte
His mantel ouer his hippes cast he
For no man schulde see his pⁱriuyte
And as he lay on deyenge in a traıı̄unnce
And wiste verrayly þat dede was he
Of honeste ȝit hadde he remembrance
Lucane to this storie I recomende
And to Swetou and to valerius also
That of þis storie writeth worde ⁊and ende
How þat þese grete conqueroures two
Fortune was first frend and sithen a foo
No man ne truste vpon his fauoᵘur longe
But haue hire in awaite eủermoo
Witnesse on alle þese conquerours stronge
This riche Cresus whilom kyng of lyde
Of whiche Cresus Ciquus sore him dradde
Ȝit was he caught amonges all his pryde
And to be brent men to þe fyre him ladde
But suche a reyn dou fro þe walken schadde
That slowh þe fyre and made him to eschape
But to be war ȝit no grace he hadde
Til fortune on þe galewes made him gape
When he eskaped was he can not stente
For to begynne anewe reyn ageyn
He wende well for þat fortune him sente
Suche hap þat he eskaped þorgh þe rayn
That of his foos he myght not be slayn
And suche a sweuene vpon a nyght he mette
Of whiche he was so proude and eke fayn
Þat in vengeance he all his herte sette
Vpon a tree he was as him þoght
There Iubiter him wisshe boþe hals ⁊and side
And phebus eke a faire towaile him broghte
To drye him and þerfore wax his pryde
And to his doghter þat stood him beside
Whiche þat he knewe in hye sentence haboıı̄unde
He bad hir telle him what hit signefied
And sche his dreme bygan right þus expoıı̄unde
The tree qd sche þe galowes is to mene
And Iubiter bytokeneth snow and reyn
And phebus with his towaile so clene
To ben þe sonne stremed forto sayn
Thou schalt anhonge fader be certayn
Reyn schal þe wasshe ⁊and sonne schal þe drye
Thus warned sche him boþe plat ⁊and playn
His doghter þat called was phanie
An honged was Cresus þe proude kyng
His royal throne myght him not availe
Tregedie is none other maner thing
Ne can in synnyg crye ne bewaile
But þat fortune alway wol assaile
With vnwar strook þe regnes þat ben proude
For when men trusteth hir þenne wole sche faile
And koủere her bright face with a cloude
Here be gynneth the prolog of the Nonne prest /
HO quod þe knyght good sire no more of this
That ȝe han seide is right I now I wys
And mochil more for litel heuynesse
Is right I now to mykel folk as I gesse
I seye for me hit is a grete disese
Where as men han ben in grete welþe ⁊and ese
To heren of her sodeyn fal allas
And þe contrarie is ioye and grete solace
As whan aman haþ be in pore estate
And clymbeth vp and wexeth fortunate
Suche þing is gladsom as hit þinketh me
And þough suche þing were goodly forto telle
Ȝe quod oure Oste by seynt poules belle
Ȝe seie right soth þis monk he clappeth loude
He spakhow fortune coued in a cloude
I not neủere what ⁊and also of a treiadie
Right now ȝe herde and ꝑparde no remedie
It is for to be wayle ne complayne
That that is doon and also hit is a payne
As ȝe han saide to here of heuynesse
Sire monk no more of þis so god ȝou blesse
Ȝoure tale annoyeth all þis companye
Suche talkyng nys not worth a butterflye
For þer Inne is no disport ne game
Wherfore sire monk daun piers by ȝoure name
I pray ȝow hertly telle vs somwhat ellys
For siker ner clinkyng of ȝoure belles
Þat on ȝoure bridel hangeþ on eủery side
By heuene kyng þat for vs all deide
I schal for þis falle dou for to slepe
Al þogh þe slowh had neủere be so depe
Than had ȝoure tale be told all in vayn
For certeynly as these Clerkes sayn
Where as aman may haue non audience
Noght helpeth to tellen his sentence
And wel I wote þe substaıı̄unce in me
If any thing schal wel reported be
Sire say somwhat of huntyng I ȝou pray
Nay quod þe monk I haue no lust to play
Now lete an other telle as I haue tolde
Than spake oure Ost with rude speche ⁊and bold
And saide vnto þe nonnes preest anon
Come nere sire preest come hider sire Iohn
Telle vs suche thinges as may oure hertes glade
Be merye þogh þou ryde vpon a iade
That þey þyn hors be foule or lene
Ȝif he wil serue the rekke þe noght a bene
Loke þat thyn herte be merye eủere mo
Ȝis oost quod he so mote I ryde or goo
But I be merye I wis I wil be blamed
And right anon he hath his tale tamed
And þus he seide to vs eủerychon
This swete preest þis good man sire Iohn

l.hi: Here endith the ꝑperlog / / And begynneth the tale

div.l: A Pore widowe somdel stope in age
Was whilom dwelling in a narow cotage
Be sides a grove stonding in a dale
This widowe of whiche I tolde ȝou my tale
Sethyns thilke day þat sche was last a wif
In pacience ladde aful simple lyf
For litel was hir catel and hire rent
By housbondrye of suche as god hir sent
Sche fand hir self and eke hir doghtren two
Thre large sowes had sche and no mo
Thre kyen and eke a schepe þat hight malle
For sotye was hire boure and eke hir halle
In whiche sche ete many a sklender mel
Of poynant sauce hir neded neủere a del
No deynte morsel passed her þrote
Hir diete was acordant to hir cote
Repleciou ne mad hir neủere sike
A tempre diete was al hire phisike
And excercise and herte suffisaunce
The goute letted hire no þing to daunce
Ne poplexie ne schent not hir hede
No wyn ne drank sche neither white ne rede
Her bord was ʆserued moste with white ⁊and blak
Milke and broıı̄un breed in whiche sche fond no lak
Seynd bachoıı̄un and somtyme an eye or tweie
For sche was as it were a mane of deye
A gardyn sche had enclosid al a boute
With stikkes and drye diche with oute
In whiche sche hadde a cok þat highte chaıı̄unteclere
In all þe lond of crowinge was his pere
His vois was murier þan þe murie orgon
On masse dayes þat in þe chirche gon
Wel sikerer was þe crowynge in his logge
Then is a clokke or any Abbay orlogge
By nature he knewe eche ascencion
Of equynoxial of thilke toıı̄un
For when degrees .xv were descended
Then knewe he that it myght not ben amended
His combe was reddere þan þe fyn corall
And batailled as it were a castel wall
I lyke aȝure were his legges and his toon
His bile was blak and as þe Ieet it schon
His nayles whitter þan þe lelye flour
And I lyke burnesshed gold was his colour
This gentil cok had in his goủernaıı̄unce
Seuene hennes forto done his plesaıı̄unce
